description.narrative:
Detta beslut avser ”Beslut om insats” (Insatshanteringsregeln 2.9 §) mellan Sida och FAO för att möjliggöra humanitärt stöd i fyra kriser 2021.
Beslutet omfattar finansiellt stöd till FAO om totalt 102 000 000 kronor, varav 94 000 000 kronor år 2021.
Sidas humanitära enhet har under 2020 genomfört en översyn av samtliga strategiska partners i syfte att säkerställa samarbete med de mest relevanta och effektiva humanitära aktörerna för genomförandet av Sveriges humanitära strategi genom Sida (2021-2025). Som ett resultat av översynen har Sida beslutat att bereda ny insats och ingå nytt strategiskt partnerskap med FAO, se beslut 2021-000057.
Syftet för beslutet är att stödja FAO:s humanitära verksamhet under 2021 samt ingå strategiskt partnerskap för perioden 2021 – 2025.
Genom stödet till FAO kommer Sida under 2021 bidra till FAO:s operativa verksamhet i Afghanistan, Nigeria, Somalia och Sydsudan. Vidare kommer Sida bidra med medel till FAO:s snabbinsatsmekanism SFERA samt med medel till det globala livsmedelsklustret.
Stödet utbetalas i början av året för att FAO ska ha förutsättningar att planera och genomföra humanitära insatser utan fördröjning. FAO omsätter regelmässigt utbetalda medel i nära anslutning till utbetalning och förbrukar gåvomedel inom verksamhetsåret.

The Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) is a specialised agency of the United Nations that leads international efforts to defeat hunger. The organisation's goal is to achieve food security for all and make sure that people have regular access to enough high-quality food to lead active, healthy lives. With over 194 member states, FAO works in over 130 countries worldwide.
FAO works side by side with the other two Rome-based UN agencies – the World Food Programme (WFP) and the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) to promote food security by alleviating hunger through emergency food assistance as well as more long-term support to eliminate the root causes of food insecurity. While WFP’s main comparative advantage lies in its capacity for large-scale food response, logistics, telecommunications and procurement capacity, the advantage of FAO lies in its role as the world’s agricultural knowledge agency with its unique agricultural expertise but also in its holistic approach to humanitarian crises, which includes analysis of the entire food system, including cultivation, harvesting, processing, packaging, transporting, marketing and consumption.
FAO also plays an important normative role, through international agreements, codes of conduct, and voluntary guidelines as well as policy dialogue at global, regional and national levels and advocacy in areas relevant to FAO’s mandate.
Alignment with strategy
The objectives of FAO are in line with the strategy for Sweden's Humanitarian Assistance through Sida (2021-2025) and through its operations, FAO is strengthening the capacity and effectiveness of the humanitarian system. The contribution is relevant for all objectives in the strategy, with an emphasis on the strategy area on protection and assistance to crisis affected populations.
This is an appraisal and subsequent decision of a new contribution (Decision on Contribution, Rule for Managing Contributions 2.9 §) between Sida and FAO, to allow for humanitarian response in four crises for 2021.
This decision also includes support for rapid response to new and deteriorating humanitarian crises through the Special Fund for Emergency and Rehabilitation Activities (SFERA) and Method-Development support through the Global Food Security Cluster.
This decision concerns a financial contribution to FAO amounting to 102 000 000 SEK.
Reasons for the decision
Evaluation 2020
During 2020, the humanitarian assistance unit at Sida conducted an overview of ongoing strategic partnerships in order to ensure that partnership was established with the most relevant and effective humanitarian actors to carry out Sweden’s strategy for humanitarian assistance through Sida (2021 – 2025). As a result of the overview, Sida has decided to appraise a new contribution and enter into a new strategic partnership agreement with FAO, see decision 2021-000057.
Comparative Advantage of FAO:
Based on the organisation’s mandate to build a world without hunger through technical cooperation and assistance, FAO has a unique role to play in humanitarian settings. Through its long-standing country presence, technical expertise in agriculture and food systems, as well as expertise and experience in both humanitarian assistance and development cooperation, FAO is well-placed to address both acute hunger as well as to support countries experiencing food crises to return to normality and building resilience to future chocks. By protecting livelihoods through emergency agricultural assistance, FAO is hence able to provide emergency interventions that save lives and safeguard livelihoods in the short-term while at the same time strengthening resilience in the face of future crises.
FAO’s comparative advantages were also highlighted by Sida’s evaluation of its strategic partners, which stated that FAO, apart from being a strong player within the thematic areas of food security and livelihoods, also demonstrated strong capacity regarding resilience and nexus programming. The evaluation also concluded that FAO has a comparative advantage in its utilisation of partnerships with local actors and development agencies, which not only ensure sustainability of its interventions but also in many cases means that FAO has good indirect access in remote and hard to reach areas. Finally, the evaluation also recognised FAO’s technical expertise as a valuable comparative advantage and highlighted FAO’s participation in technical working groups and its leadership role in the food security clusters as well as its contribution to HNO/HRP processes. Specifically, the evaluation highlighted the Sida supported FSNAU intervention as an example of an FAO intervention that was instrumental in providing early warning to the humanitarian system in Somalia, which contributed to avert famine during the severe drought in 2017.
Sida’s Humanitarian Follow Up and Field Missions to FAO Responses:
Due to the COVID-19 pandemic the staff at Sida’s unit for humanitarian assistance based in Stockholm were not able to make as many field follow-ups as per normal. Humanitarian focal points stationed in the Foreign Missions have been crucial to conduct follow-up, as well as digital tools that have allowed for remote monitoring and follow-up. Overall, the conclusions of continuous dialogue, monitoring and follow-up show that FAO is a professional humanitarian actor which, through its extensive network of partners, has the ability to gain access to very remote and hard to reach areas. Sida also notes that FAO in several contexts through its vast technical expertise, plays an important role in technical working groups and coordination fora in the project countries.
THE GLOBAL HUMANITARIAN SITUATION 2021
According to the Global Humanitarian Overview, in 2021, 235 million people will be in need of humanitarian assistance and protection – a substantial increase compared to 2020 which started out with nearly 168 million people in need. Thus resulting in yet another year with the highest number of people in need ever recorded by the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA). In parallel with staggering numbers of people in need, the funding gap increases and according to OCHA’s Financial Tracking Service (FTS), response plans and appeals were only 46% funded in 2020, compared to 61% in 2019. In 2021 the UN and partner organisations aim to help 160 million people most in need across 56 countries, with an estimated requirement of 35 billion USD.
Both the increase in people in need and funding gap can be partly derived from the COVID-19 pandemic. Putting additional pressure onto an already strained humanitarian system with limited resources. Although COVID-19 has definitely been centre stage during 2020, there are still other worrying trends affecting the global humanitarian outlook for 2021.
First, the COVID-19 pandemic has further exacerbated the vulnerability of the least protected populations. The pandemic has triggered the deepest global recession since the 1930s. Extreme poverty has risen for the first time in 22 years, and unemployment has increased dramatically. The impact of the socio-economic situation will continue to have serious implications on humanitarian needs in 2021.
Second, political conflicts are more intense and are taking a heavy toll on civilians, disproportionally affecting children. Women and girls are at increased risk of conflict-related sexual violence. As such, protecting those affected by armed conflict is more crucial than ever. The lack of respect for International Humanitarian Law (IHL) continues to be one of the most pressing challenges. Armed conflicts continue to cause enormous suffering, including violations of IHL, such as killings, torture, abductions and displacements. Applying a protection lens/Centrality of Protection approach is essential – in light of the protection crises such as the Syria crisis - now active for more than a decade; Yemen - being the largest humanitarian crisis worldwide; the DR Congo; the Venezuela crisis; the Nagorno-Karabach situation and the Rohingya crisis – just to mention a few.
Third, hunger is on the rise, with conflict the main driver of acute hunger for 77 million people in 22 countries. By the end of 2020, the number of acutely food insecure people could be 270 million. The impacts of the pandemic and climate change are seriously affecting food systems worldwide.
Fourth, climate change exacerbate humanitarian needs and extreme weather events. The desert locust outbreak from late 2019 was the worst in 25 years in the Horn of Africa. A series of flooding situations have taken place in 2020 where we have seen increased humanitarian needs and the displacement of vulnerable populations in contexts such as Sahel, South-East Asia, Sudan, Afghanistan, Ethiopia and South Sudan.
Fifth, as a result of the above, displacements are at record high levels. Conflict, violence and natural disasters drive people to seek refuge in either their country of origin or by crossing international borders. The majority of the 80 million people living in displacement have been forced to seek refuge due to natural disasters. The number of refugees, most of which seek refuge in neighbouring countries, has doubled from 10 million to 20 million in 10 years.
Sida’s humanitarian allocation to FAO in 2021
Sida´s humanitarian assistance is based on the four humanitarian principles, in particular impartiality, with its compelling urge to ensure that humanitarian action is carried out based on needs alone, giving priority to the most urgent cases of distress. Hence, Sida’s allocation methodology is grounded in several objective indicators such as; the scale of humanitarian needs (number of people in need), the severity of humanitarian needs (including food insecurity/IPC levels), the number of people targeted for the humanitarian response, the financial coverage of the respective humanitarian appeal, national capacities to respond and underlying risks, as well as distinct indicators related to forgotten crises. The allocation and subsequent disbursement of funds takes place in the beginning of the year to ensure predictability for Sida’s strategic humanitarian partners and to allow for optimal operational planning.
Based on Sida's humanitarian needs-based allocation process in late 2020 the following is proposed for FAO in 2021:
- Annual Projects/Programmes in line with Humanitarian Response Plans (usually 12 months) - 67 000 000 SEK - Rapid Response Mechanism (SFERA) - 25 000 000 SEK - Method Development and Capacity-Building - 2 000 000 SEK
This means that the total initial contribution to FAO in 2021 amounts to 94 000 000 SEK.
Annual Projects/Programmes (in line with the 2021 Humanitarian Response Plans):
- Afghanistan: 30 000 000 SEK
- Nigeria: 9 000 000 SEK
- Somalia: 12 000 000 SEK
- Somalia (FSNAU): 4 000 000 SEK
- South Sudan: 12 000 000 SEK
Rapid Response Mechanism or unallocated funds:
- SFERA: 25 000 000 SEK
Method- and capacity-building support
- Global Food Security Cluster: 2 000 000 SEK

FAO’s Global Goals are: 1. Eradication of hunger, food insecurity and malnutrition, progressively ensuring a world in which people at all times have sufficient safe and nutritious food that meets their dietary needs and food preferences for an active and healthy life; 2. Elimination of poverty and the driving forward of economic and social progress for all, with increased food production, enhanced rural development and sustainable livelihoods; 3. Sustainable management and utilization of natural resources, including land, water, air, climate and genetic resources for the benefit of present and future generations. Detta beslut avser ”Beslut om insats” (Insatshanteringsregeln 2.9 §) mellan Sida och FAO för att möjliggöra humanitärt stöd i fyra kriser 2021.
Beslutet omfattar finansiellt stöd till FAO om totalt 102 000 000 kronor, varav 94 000 000 kronor år 2021.
Sidas humanitära enhet har under 2020 genomfört en översyn av samtliga strategiska partners i syfte att säkerställa samarbete med de mest relevanta och effektiva humanitära aktörerna för genomförandet av Sveriges humanitära strategi genom Sida (2021-2025). Som ett resultat av översynen har Sida beslutat att bereda ny insats och ingå nytt strategiskt partnerskap med FAO, se beslut 2021-000057.
Syftet för beslutet är att stödja FAO:s humanitära verksamhet under 2021 samt ingå strategiskt partnerskap för perioden 2021 – 2025.
Genom stödet till FAO kommer Sida under 2021 bidra till FAO:s operativa verksamhet i Afghanistan, Nigeria, Somalia och Sydsudan. Vidare kommer Sida bidra med medel till FAO:s snabbinsatsmekanism SFERA samt med medel till det globala livsmedelsklustret.
Stödet utbetalas i början av året för att FAO ska ha förutsättningar att planera och genomföra humanitära insatser utan fördröjning. FAO omsätter regelmässigt utbetalda medel i nära anslutning till utbetalning och förbrukar gåvomedel inom verksamhetsåret.

The Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) is a specialised agency of the United Nations that leads international efforts to defeat hunger. The organisation's goal is to achieve food security for all and make sure that people have regular access to enough high-quality food to lead active, healthy lives. With over 194 member states, FAO works in over 130 countries worldwide.
FAO works side by side with the other two Rome-based UN agencies – the World Food Programme (WFP) and the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) to promote food security by alleviating hunger through emergency food assistance as well as more long-term support to eliminate the root causes of food insecurity. While WFP’s main comparative advantage lies in its capacity for large-scale food response, logistics, telecommunications and procurement capacity, the advantage of FAO lies in its role as the world’s agricultural knowledge agency with its unique agricultural expertise but also in its holistic approach to humanitarian crises, which includes analysis of the entire food system, including cultivation, harvesting, processing, packaging, transporting, marketing and consumption.
FAO also plays an important normative role, through international agreements, codes of conduct, and voluntary guidelines as well as policy dialogue at global, regional and national levels and advocacy in areas relevant to FAO’s mandate.
Alignment with strategy
The objectives of FAO are in line with the strategy for Sweden's Humanitarian Assistance through Sida (2021-2025) and through its operations, FAO is strengthening the capacity and effectiveness of the humanitarian system. The contribution is relevant for all objectives in the strategy, with an emphasis on the strategy area on protection and assistance to crisis affected populations.
This is an appraisal and subsequent decision of a new contribution (Decision on Contribution, Rule for Managing Contributions 2.9 §) between Sida and FAO, to allow for humanitarian response in four crises for 2021.
This decision also includes support for rapid response to new and deteriorating humanitarian crises through the Special Fund for Emergency and Rehabilitation Activities (SFERA) and Method-Development support through the Global Food Security Cluster.
This decision concerns a financial contribution to FAO amounting to 102 000 000 SEK.
Reasons for the decision
Evaluation 2020
During 2020, the humanitarian assistance unit at Sida conducted an overview of ongoing strategic partnerships in order to ensure that partnership was established with the most relevant and effective humanitarian actors to carry out Sweden’s strategy for humanitarian assistance through Sida (2021 – 2025). As a result of the overview, Sida has decided to appraise a new contribution and enter into a new strategic partnership agreement with FAO, see decision 2021-000057.
Comparative Advantage of FAO:
Based on the organisation’s mandate to build a world without hunger through technical cooperation and assistance, FAO has a unique role to play in humanitarian settings. Through its long-standing country presence, technical expertise in agriculture and food systems, as well as expertise and experience in both humanitarian assistance and development cooperation, FAO is well-placed to address both acute hunger as well as to support countries experiencing food crises to return to normality and building resilience to future chocks. By protecting livelihoods through emergency agricultural assistance, FAO is hence able to provide emergency interventions that save lives and safeguard livelihoods in the short-term while at the same time strengthening resilience in the face of future crises.
FAO’s comparative advantages were also highlighted by Sida’s evaluation of its strategic partners, which stated that FAO, apart from being a strong player within the thematic areas of food security and livelihoods, also demonstrated strong capacity regarding resilience and nexus programming. The evaluation also concluded that FAO has a comparative advantage in its utilisation of partnerships with local actors and development agencies, which not only ensure sustainability of its interventions but also in many cases means that FAO has good indirect access in remote and hard to reach areas. Finally, the evaluation also recognised FAO’s technical expertise as a valuable comparative advantage and highlighted FAO’s participation in technical working groups and its leadership role in the food security clusters as well as its contribution to HNO/HRP processes. Specifically, the evaluation highlighted the Sida supported FSNAU intervention as an example of an FAO intervention that was instrumental in providing early warning to the humanitarian system in Somalia, which contributed to avert famine during the severe drought in 2017.
Sida’s Humanitarian Follow Up and Field Missions to FAO Responses:
Due to the COVID-19 pandemic the staff at Sida’s unit for humanitarian assistance based in Stockholm were not able to make as many field follow-ups as per normal. Humanitarian focal points stationed in the Foreign Missions have been crucial to conduct follow-up, as well as digital tools that have allowed for remote monitoring and follow-up. Overall, the conclusions of continuous dialogue, monitoring and follow-up show that FAO is a professional humanitarian actor which, through its extensive network of partners, has the ability to gain access to very remote and hard to reach areas. Sida also notes that FAO in several contexts through its vast technical expertise, plays an important role in technical working groups and coordination fora in the project countries.
THE GLOBAL HUMANITARIAN SITUATION 2021
According to the Global Humanitarian Overview, in 2021, 235 million people will be in need of humanitarian assistance and protection – a substantial increase compared to 2020 which started out with nearly 168 million people in need. Thus resulting in yet another year with the highest number of people in need ever recorded by the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA). In parallel with staggering numbers of people in need, the funding gap increases and according to OCHA’s Financial Tracking Service (FTS), response plans and appeals were only 46% funded in 2020, compared to 61% in 2019. In 2021 the UN and partner organisations aim to help 160 million people most in need across 56 countries, with an estimated requirement of 35 billion USD.
Both the increase in people in need and funding gap can be partly derived from the COVID-19 pandemic. Putting additional pressure onto an already strained humanitarian system with limited resources. Although COVID-19 has definitely been centre stage during 2020, there are still other worrying trends affecting the global humanitarian outlook for 2021.
First, the COVID-19 pandemic has further exacerbated the vulnerability of the least protected populations. The pandemic has triggered the deepest global recession since the 1930s. Extreme poverty has risen for the first time in 22 years, and unemployment has increased dramatically. The impact of the socio-economic situation will continue to have serious implications on humanitarian needs in 2021.
Second, political conflicts are more intense and are taking a heavy toll on civilians, disproportionally affecting children. Women and girls are at increased risk of conflict-related sexual violence. As such, protecting those affected by armed conflict is more crucial than ever. The lack of respect for International Humanitarian Law (IHL) continues to be one of the most pressing challenges. Armed conflicts continue to cause enormous suffering, including violations of IHL, such as killings, torture, abductions and displacements. Applying a protection lens/Centrality of Protection approach is essential – in light of the protection crises such as the Syria crisis - now active for more than a decade; Yemen - being the largest humanitarian crisis worldwide; the DR Congo; the Venezuela crisis; the Nagorno-Karabach situation and the Rohingya crisis – just to mention a few.
Third, hunger is on the rise, with conflict the main driver of acute hunger for 77 million people in 22 countries. By the end of 2020, the number of acutely food insecure people could be 270 million. The impacts of the pandemic and climate change are seriously affecting food systems worldwide.
Fourth, climate change exacerbate humanitarian needs and extreme weather events. The desert locust outbreak from late 2019 was the worst in 25 years in the Horn of Africa. A series of flooding situations have taken place in 2020 where we have seen increased humanitarian needs and the displacement of vulnerable populations in contexts such as Sahel, South-East Asia, Sudan, Afghanistan, Ethiopia and South Sudan.
Fifth, as a result of the above, displacements are at record high levels. Conflict, violence and natural disasters drive people to seek refuge in either their country of origin or by crossing international borders. The majority of the 80 million people living in displacement have been forced to seek refuge due to natural disasters. The number of refugees, most of which seek refuge in neighbouring countries, has doubled from 10 million to 20 million in 10 years.
Sida’s humanitarian allocation to FAO in 2021
Sida´s humanitarian assistance is based on the four humanitarian principles, in particular impartiality, with its compelling urge to ensure that humanitarian action is carried out based on needs alone, giving priority to the most urgent cases of distress. Hence, Sida’s allocation methodology is grounded in several objective indicators such as; the scale of humanitarian needs (number of people in need), the severity of humanitarian needs (including food insecurity/IPC levels), the number of people targeted for the humanitarian response, the financial coverage of the respective humanitarian appeal, national capacities to respond and underlying risks, as well as distinct indicators related to forgotten crises. The allocation and subsequent disbursement of funds takes place in the beginning of the year to ensure predictability for Sida’s strategic humanitarian partners and to allow for optimal operational planning.
Based on Sida's humanitarian needs-based allocation process in late 2020 the following is proposed for FAO in 2021:
- Annual Projects/Programmes in line with Humanitarian Response Plans (usually 12 months) - 67 000 000 SEK - Rapid Response Mechanism (SFERA) - 25 000 000 SEK - Method Development and Capacity-Building - 2 000 000 SEK
This means that the total initial contribution to FAO in 2021 amounts to 94 000 000 SEK.
Annual Projects/Programmes (in line with the 2021 Humanitarian Response Plans):
- Afghanistan: 30 000 000 SEK
- Nigeria: 9 000 000 SEK
- Somalia: 12 000 000 SEK
- Somalia (FSNAU): 4 000 000 SEK
- South Sudan: 12 000 000 SEK
Rapid Response Mechanism or unallocated funds:
- SFERA: 25 000 000 SEK
Method- and capacity-building support
- Global Food Security Cluster: 2 000 000 SEK

FAO also plays an important normative role, through international agreements, codes of conduct, and voluntary guidelines as well as policy dialogue at global, regional and national levels and advocacy in areas relevant to FAO’s mandate.
Alignment with strategy
The objectives of FAO are in line with the strategy for Sweden's Humanitarian Assistance through Sida (2021-2025) and through its operations, FAO is strengthening the capacity and effectiveness of the humanitarian system. The contribution is relevant for all objectives in the strategy, with an emphasis on the strategy area on protection and assistance to crisis affected populations.
This is an appraisal and subsequent decision of a new contribution (Decision on Contribution, Rule for Managing Contributions 2.9 §) between Sida and FAO, to allow for humanitarian response in four crises for 2021.
This decision also includes support for rapid response to new and deteriorating humanitarian crises through the Special Fund for Emergency and Rehabilitation Activities (SFERA) and Method-Development support through the Global Food Security Cluster.
This decision concerns a financial contribution to FAO amounting to 102 000 000 SEK.
Reasons for the decision
Evaluation 2020
During 2020, the humanitarian assistance unit at Sida conducted an overview of ongoing strategic partnerships in order to ensure that partnership was established with the most relevant and effective humanitarian actors to carry out Sweden’s strategy for humanitarian assistance through Sida (2021 – 2025). As a result of the overview, Sida has decided to appraise a new contribution and enter into a new strategic partnership agreement with FAO, see decision 2021-000057.
Comparative Advantage of FAO:
Based on the organisation’s mandate to build a world without hunger through technical cooperation and assistance, FAO has a unique role to play in humanitarian settings. Through its long-standing country presence, technical expertise in agriculture and food systems, as well as expertise and experience in both humanitarian assistance and development cooperation, FAO is well-placed to address both acute hunger as well as to support countries experiencing food crises to return to normality and building resilience to future chocks. By protecting livelihoods through emergency agricultural assistance, FAO is hence able to provide emergency interventions that save lives and safeguard livelihoods in the short-term while at the same time strengthening resilience in the face of future crises.
FAO’s comparative advantages were also highlighted by Sida’s evaluation of its strategic partners, which stated that FAO, apart from being a strong player within the thematic areas of food security and livelihoods, also demonstrated strong capacity regarding resilience and nexus programming. The evaluation also concluded that FAO has a comparative advantage in its utilisation of partnerships with local actors and development agencies, which not only ensure sustainability of its interventions but also in many cases means that FAO has good indirect access in remote and hard to reach areas. Finally, the evaluation also recognised FAO’s technical expertise as a valuable comparative advantage and highlighted FAO’s participation in technical working groups and its leadership role in the food security clusters as well as its contribution to HNO/HRP processes. Specifically, the evaluation highlighted the Sida supported FSNAU intervention as an example of an FAO intervention that was instrumental in providing early warning to the humanitarian system in Somalia, which contributed to avert famine during the severe drought in 2017.
Sida’s Humanitarian Follow Up and Field Missions to FAO Responses:
Due to the COVID-19 pandemic the staff at Sida’s unit for humanitarian assistance based in Stockholm were not able to make as many field follow-ups as per normal. Humanitarian focal points stationed in the Foreign Missions have been crucial to conduct follow-up, as well as digital tools that have allowed for remote monitoring and follow-up. Overall, the conclusions of continuous dialogue, monitoring and follow-up show that FAO is a professional humanitarian actor which, through its extensive network of partners, has the ability to gain access to very remote and hard to reach areas. Sida also notes that FAO in several contexts through its vast technical expertise, plays an important role in technical working groups and coordination fora in the project countries.
THE GLOBAL HUMANITARIAN SITUATION 2021
According to the Global Humanitarian Overview, in 2021, 235 million people will be in need of humanitarian assistance and protection – a substantial increase compared to 2020 which started out with nearly 168 million people in need. Thus resulting in yet another year with the highest number of people in need ever recorded by the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA). In parallel with staggering numbers of people in need, the funding gap increases and according to OCHA’s Financial Tracking Service (FTS), response plans and appeals were only 46% funded in 2020, compared to 61% in 2019. In 2021 the UN and partner organisations aim to help 160 million people most in need across 56 countries, with an estimated requirement of 35 billion USD.
Both the increase in people in need and funding gap can be partly derived from the COVID-19 pandemic. Putting additional pressure onto an already strained humanitarian system with limited resources. Although COVID-19 has definitely been centre stage during 2020, there are still other worrying trends affecting the global humanitarian outlook for 2021.
First, the COVID-19 pandemic has further exacerbated the vulnerability of the least protected populations. The pandemic has triggered the deepest global recession since the 1930s. Extreme poverty has risen for the first time in 22 years, and unemployment has increased dramatically. The impact of the socio-economic situation will continue to have serious implications on humanitarian needs in 2021.
Second, political conflicts are more intense and are taking a heavy toll on civilians, disproportionally affecting children. Women and girls are at increased risk of conflict-related sexual violence. As such, protecting those affected by armed conflict is more crucial than ever. The lack of respect for International Humanitarian Law (IHL) continues to be one of the most pressing challenges. Armed conflicts continue to cause enormous suffering, including violations of IHL, such as killings, torture, abductions and displacements. Applying a protection lens/Centrality of Protection approach is essential – in light of the protection crises such as the Syria crisis - now active for more than a decade; Yemen - being the largest humanitarian crisis worldwide; the DR Congo; the Venezuela crisis; the Nagorno-Karabach situation and the Rohingya crisis – just to mention a few.
Third, hunger is on the rise, with conflict the main driver of acute hunger for 77 million people in 22 countries. By the end of 2020, the number of acutely food insecure people could be 270 million. The impacts of the pandemic and climate change are seriously affecting food systems worldwide.
Fourth, climate change exacerbate humanitarian needs and extreme weather events. The desert locust outbreak from late 2019 was the worst in 25 years in the Horn of Africa. A series of flooding situations have taken place in 2020 where we have seen increased humanitarian needs and the displacement of vulnerable populations in contexts such as Sahel, South-East Asia, Sudan, Afghanistan, Ethiopia and South Sudan.
Fifth, as a result of the above, displacements are at record high levels. Conflict, violence and natural disasters drive people to seek refuge in either their country of origin or by crossing international borders. The majority of the 80 million people living in displacement have been forced to seek refuge due to natural disasters. The number of refugees, most of which seek refuge in neighbouring countries, has doubled from 10 million to 20 million in 10 years.
Sida’s humanitarian allocation to FAO in 2021
Sida´s humanitarian assistance is based on the four humanitarian principles, in particular impartiality, with its compelling urge to ensure that humanitarian action is carried out based on needs alone, giving priority to the most urgent cases of distress. Hence, Sida’s allocation methodology is grounded in several objective indicators such as; the scale of humanitarian needs (number of people in need), the severity of humanitarian needs (including food insecurity/IPC levels), the number of people targeted for the humanitarian response, the financial coverage of the respective humanitarian appeal, national capacities to respond and underlying risks, as well as distinct indicators related to forgotten crises. The allocation and subsequent disbursement of funds takes place in the beginning of the year to ensure predictability for Sida’s strategic humanitarian partners and to allow for optimal operational planning.
Based on Sida's humanitarian needs-based allocation process in late 2020 the following is proposed for FAO in 2021:
- Annual Projects/Programmes in line with Humanitarian Response Plans (usually 12 months) - 67 000 000 SEK - Rapid Response Mechanism (SFERA) - 25 000 000 SEK - Method Development and Capacity-Building - 2 000 000 SEK
This means that the total initial contribution to FAO in 2021 amounts to 94 000 000 SEK.
Annual Projects/Programmes (in line with the 2021 Humanitarian Response Plans):
- Afghanistan: 30 000 000 SEK
- Nigeria: 9 000 000 SEK
- Somalia: 12 000 000 SEK
- Somalia (FSNAU): 4 000 000 SEK
- South Sudan: 12 000 000 SEK
Rapid Response Mechanism or unallocated funds:
- SFERA: 25 000 000 SEK
Method- and capacity-building support
- Global Food Security Cluster: 2 000 000 SEK

FAO’s Global Goals are: 1. Eradication of hunger, food insecurity and malnutrition, progressively ensuring a world in which people at all times have sufficient safe and nutritious food that meets their dietary needs and food preferences for an active and healthy life; 2. Elimination of poverty and the driving forward of economic and social progress for all, with increased food production, enhanced rural development and sustainable livelihoods; 3. Sustainable management and utilization of natural resources, including land, water, air, climate and genetic resources for the benefit of present and future generations. Based on the global goals, FAO has formulated five strategic objectives: 1. Contribute to the eradication of hunger, food insecurity and malnutrition 2. Make agriculture, forestry and fisheries more productive and sustainable 3. Reduce rural poverty 4. Enable more inclusive and efficient agricultural and food systems 5. Increase the resilience of livelihoods to threats and crises The Strategic Framework also includes a sixth, broad objective on technical quality, knowledge and services (including cross-cutting themes) that is designed to cover FAO’s internal capability to deliver its strategic objectives. The objectives are in alignment with FAO’s commitment to working in partnerships. In humanitarian crises, FAO’s main components are: To help people to anticipate and prepare for crises; To respond fast to crises; To seek to reduce risks and address vulnerabilities. The humanitarian operations are usually related to the 5th strategic objective which has the four following organizational outcomes (OO): OO1 - countries and regions have legal, policy and institutional systems and regulatory frameworks for disaster and crisis risk management for agriculture, food and nutrition; OO2 - countries and regions deliver regular information and trigger timely actions against potential, known and emerging threats to agriculture, food, and nutrition; OO3 - countries apply prevention and impact mitigation measures that reduce risks for agriculture, food and nutrition; OO4 - countries and regions affected by disasters and crises with impact on agriculture, food and nutrition are prepared for, and manage effective responses. At the next level in the FAO Strategic Framework, there are a number of outputs pertinent to humanitarian action, such as: Output 4.1: Humanitarian action effectively protect lives and livelihoods of farmers, herders, Fishers, forest- and tree-dependent communities and marginal groups in times of crises. Output 3.1: Strategies and related interventions improve the resilience of livelihoods systems at risk through prevention and mitigation efforts that minimize the potential impacts of disasters and crises on agriculture food and nutrition at national, subnational and community levels. Output 2.2: Improved capacities of countries and communities to identify monitor and evaluate risks; conduct needs assessment and response analysis; and act on impending threats to agriculture, nutrition, food security and food safety (and related public health issues). Output 3.3: Conflict-sensitive programmes on agriculture, food and nutrition reduce the risks of localized conflicts relating to access to grazing, forest and farming lands, fishing grounds, water, trees and other natural resources. As Sida support FAO’s operations through a variety of different projects in different contexts, this appraisal does not include an overarching results framework. In the annual follow up reading up to Sida’s conclusion on performance all individual project reports will be analysed and assessed.

Detta beslut avser ”Beslut om insats” (Insatshanteringsregeln 2.9 §) mellan Sida och FAO för att möjliggöra humanitärt stöd i fyra kriser 2021.
Beslutet omfattar finansiellt stöd till FAO om totalt 102 000 000 kronor, varav 94 000 000 kronor år 2021.
Sidas humanitära enhet har under 2020 genomfört en översyn av samtliga strategiska partners i syfte att säkerställa samarbete med de mest relevanta och effektiva humanitära aktörerna för genomförandet av Sveriges humanitära strategi genom Sida (2021-2025). Som ett resultat av översynen har Sida beslutat att bereda ny insats och ingå nytt strategiskt partnerskap med FAO, se beslut 2021-000057.
Syftet för beslutet är att stödja FAO:s humanitära verksamhet under 2021 samt ingå strategiskt partnerskap för perioden 2021 – 2025.
Genom stödet till FAO kommer Sida under 2021 bidra till FAO:s operativa verksamhet i Afghanistan, Nigeria, Somalia och Sydsudan. Vidare kommer Sida bidra med medel till FAO:s snabbinsatsmekanism SFERA samt med medel till det globala livsmedelsklustret.
Stödet utbetalas i början av året för att FAO ska ha förutsättningar att planera och genomföra humanitära insatser utan fördröjning. FAO omsätter regelmässigt utbetalda medel i nära anslutning till utbetalning och förbrukar gåvomedel inom verksamhetsåret.

Oxfam har ansökt om 75 miljoner SEK under 2021, varav 36 miljoner SEK tilldelas för att genomföra humanitära projekt i Algeriet, Centralafrikanska Republiken, Colombia och Tchad; 30 miljoner SEK för den humanitära snabbmekanismen; och 9 miljoner SEK för metod- och kapacitetsstöd samt programhanteringsstöd. Insatsen utgör första året av ett strategiskt partnerskap som sträcker sig mellan 2021 och 2025 mellan Oxfam och Sidas humanitära enhet.
Målet med insatsen är att skyndsamt kunna nå människor med humanitärt stöd i akuta kriser samt att bidra till att stärka kapaciteten i det humanitära systemet. Samtliga föreslagna insatser vägleds av Oxfams kärnmandat, vilket är att arbeta med samhällen innan, under och efter kriser för att bygga upp deras motståndskraft, rädda liv och tillsammans angripa orsakerna till konflikt och andra katastrofer.
Oxfam är en global hjälporganisation som arbetar med människor mot fattigdom över hela världen. Oxfam:s vision är en rättvis värld utan fattigdom, där alla värderas och behandlas lika, har samma rättigheter och kan påverka sin egen framtid. Oxfam arbetar på flera nivåer, genom livräddande katastrofinsatser, långsiktiga projekt som ger människor möjlighet att lyfta sig ur fattigdom och politisk påverkan lindrar vi de akuta symptomen. Oxfam GB är ett av 20 medlemmar som utgör konfederationen Oxfam International.

Oxfam has submitted a proposal for financing to Sida for humanitarian response in the following contexts in 2021: Algeria, Central African Republic (CAR), Chad, and Colombia. The proposal includes a request for Oxfam’s rapid response mechanism (RRM) and for method and capacity support.
The contribution will be the first year of a strategic partnership that extends between 2021 and 2025 between Oxfam and Sida's Humanitarian Unit. The aim of the contribution is to reach people affected by crisis with humanitarian assistance and protection and to contribute to strengthening the capacity of the humanitarian system. All proposed efforts are guided by Oxfam's core mandate, which is to work with communities before, during and after crises to build their resilience, save lives and tackle the causes of conflict and other disasters.
Oxfam is a global movement of people who are fighting inequality to end poverty and injustice. Oxfam works in about 70 countries, with partners, and allies. Oxfam GB is one of 20 affiliates that make up the confederation Oxfam International.

This contribution is aimed at supporting Oxfam in selected humanitarian crisis where Oxfam will implement specific projects and where the organisation has a clear added value to provide humanitarian assistance and protection to crisis affected populations. In 2020 Oxfam launched its new Global Strategic Framework 2020-2030. The framework was developed over a one-year process that involved Oxfam staff and partners across its global confederation. It sets out the overall direction that Oxfam will take in the years to 2030. According to Oxfam, implementation of the framework will be supported by global horizon plans that will set out specific objectives, systemic interventions, and actions. These plans will serve as a roadmaps for measuring progress towards Oxfam’s collective ambition. A combination of six approaches is presented in the framework and will constitute Oxfam’s overarching theory of change. These include: A feminist approach- To end all forms of discrimination, injustices and violations of rights suffered by women and gender non-conforming people People power – Amplify the voices and actions of people that experience poverty and injustice and work with those who fight for their causes Thinking globally and acting locally- Build a coalition within and between regions and from the local to the global Enhanced humanitarian action- remain committed to delivering life-saving assistance and protection in times of conflict and disaster Digital rights and space- to engage with and leverage the power and influence of digital technology Systematic change – Mobilize to transform the systems that perpetuate poverty and injustice. The strategy also outlines Oxfam’s approach to enhance its humanitarian actions which involves 1) deliveing life-saving support and assistance to communities affected by conflict and disaster, including people on the move; 2) transforming the systems that contribute to fragility and humanitarian crises;3) helping people and communities develop core competencies to strengthen their resilience; 4) continue to reorient the humanitarian system towards local leadership, and; 5) expanding opportunities for those impacted by protracted conflict and recurring crises to lead on sustainable solutions. At the operational level the global strategic framework reaffirms Oxfam’s commitment to humanitarian assistance in the technical areas of WASH, Economic Inclusion, Cash and social protection based approaches, Gender, Community based protection and safe programming, and finally advocacy work to complement programmes in particular on women in conflict. In all the technical areas there are four pillars that will inform the humanitarian approach including 1) Community Engagement; 2) Safe Programming; 3) Partnership and Leadership, 4) Feminist approach. Oxfam is currently working on its Horizon Plan for humanitarian action, which will give practical and pragmatic guidance on expectations for Oxfam countries on its humanitarian ambition, how it is changing in approach and alignment of appropriate support. In 2021/2022 Sida will support Oxfam’s humanitarian interventions in 4 different crises as well as its immediate response to new onset crises or rapidly deteriorating situations through the rapid response mechanisms (RRM). The specific objective of each project might differ, but Oxfam’s core objective within its humanitarian mandate is to work with communities before, during and after crisis to build their resilience, save lives, and together address the root causes of conflict and disaster. Sida will also support a project implemented by Oxfam to improve the use of the Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC) analysis as a tool for ascertaining food insecurity, as well as support to CaLP in order to strengthen the system wide use of CVA as a modality in humanitarian interventions. The following provides a brief description of the projects objectives and intended results: Algeria (10 MSEK) – Refugees from Western Sahara have been living in 5 refugee camps in Tindouf region, southwestern Algeria since 1975 due to an on-going dispute over the control of the Western Sahara Territory. With no imminent political solution to this protracted crisis in sight, the refugee population is largely dependent on external humanitarian aid for its survival. 94% of refugees remain dependent on humanitarian aid as their primary source of support, including for the provision of food, water and other basic needs. The intervention aims to strengthen the resilience amongst 133 672 Sahrawi refugees to meet their basic needs, with a focus on food security and water and sanitation. Food security will be improved through the promotion of local agricultural production and distribution of fresh food during challenging summer months. In line with the official UN 5-year WaSH Strategy and Plan, the piped water network in Boujdour camp (which has relied completely on water trucking to date) will be extended, serving as a model which can later be adapted and scaled up in other camps. Colombia (9 MSEK) - During 2020, refugees and migrants from Venezuela continued arriving in Colombia, with an estimated 1,7 million remaining in the country and half a million in transit to other countries. This situation was further exacerbated by the impact of natural disasters, generalized violence in certain areas, and since March, by the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. This intervention is part of Oxfam´s broad protection strategy to Venezuelan mixed migration flux. It is based on two main components: 1) a strategy to promote sexual and reproductive rights through access to short and medium-term contraceptive methods, accompanied by legal, medical and psychological counselling to manage cases of gender-based violence, and 2) a focused women migrant walkers' program that provides information to tackle risks, reduce vulnerability and strengthen capacities of migrants to avoid risks and mitigate their effects. The project targets approximately 5 000 migrants with protection and NFI assistance. Central African Republic (CAR) (10 MSEK) - Clashes between rebels and government forces in various cities has caused further deterioration of the security situation in CAR since late December 2020, resulting in 105 000 new refugees and 100 000 new IDPs in the beginning of February 2021. The situation affects the sectors of food security; water, hygiene and sanitation; protection and gender, and particularly affects the prefectures of Ouham, Ouham-Pendé and Mbomou in which the project will be implemented. The intervention aims to improve the protection and living conditions of displaced, returnee and host communities in the target areas by strengthening access to food security and livelihoods, improving access to WASH services and building the capacity of affected populations to prevent and respond to protection risks. The project will target approximately 67 000 people across these three areas. In line with Oxfam’s localisation of aid commitments under the Grand Bargain and the Charter for Change, Oxfam will implement this intervention jointly with local humanitarian agencies. Chad (7 MSEK) – Chad is facing three interconnected crises: food insecurity and malnutrition, population movements (481 645 refugees, 336 124 IDPs, and 109 019 new returnees) and health emergencies. The already alarming humanitarian situation in Chad has been further weakened by the suspension of certain humanitarian activities following the implementation of restrictive measures due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The intervention will contribute to the community resilience and self-protection of the displaced populations in the Bagasola and Daboua areas in the Lake region of Chad. It will strengthen IDPs abilities to identify, respond to and mitigate risks and threats to protection. Approximately 40 000 people will be targeted. The project also aims to increase people access to water and sanitation facilities through construction and rehabilitation of waterpoints and improvement of people knowledge and practice of public health and hygiene based on community perceptions. Through cash distribution to highly vulnerable IDPs, returnees and host communities their essential food needs will be met and their livelihoods strengthened. IPC Project in CAR and Zimbabwe (3 MSEK) Specific gaps in country IPC processes have been identified by Oxfam and other stakeholders in Zimbabwe and CAR. Each country has had difficulties with data collection and data quality. In CAR, there are problems with both the quantity and the quality of data available to perform the analyses including a lack of surveys data in some geographic areas and information gaps in the available data (e.g., core food security indicators). In Zimbabwe, the government leads the data collection process and NGOs are invited to participate, but sometimes at short notice and at times with resource contributions to the data collection processes as a prerequisite for participation of agencies in IPC analyses. Large surveys organized by government or UN agencies also tend to crowd out viable sources of information produced by smaller organizations that would otherwise add value and diversity to datasets used in analyses. This interventions is expected to increase the engagement of NGOs (with a goal of at least 4-6 NGOs participating per country) and support expanded plurality in the consensus-building part of the IPC analysis workshop. Greater transparency will be seen through participation of at least two NGO representatives in the full IPC process: pre-analysis (includes primary data collection and preparation), analysis (e.g., workshops), and post-analysis (communication etc.). The project will consolidate one country-based community of practice of agencies involved in IPC per country (CAR and Zimbabwe). CaLP (4 MSEK) The Cash and Voucher Assitance (CVA) landscape is characterized by rapid change and evolving opportunities, both at global and national levels. Technological developments and the changing role of governments, private sector and local actors carry major implications for the role of international humanitarian actors. The amount spent on CVA in humanitarian response has doubled in the past three years. At the same time, overall humanitarian funding has plateaued, meaning that CVA is becoming an increasingly critical part of humanitarian response. The use of CVA has also grown in the COVID-19 response, with the Global Humanitarian Response Plan calling for a scale-up of CVA as an effective way to protect the most vulnerable, as well as reduce the deterioration of assets, livelihoods and social cohesion. The contribution to CaLP will be in support of CaLPs annual plan (2021-2022). The plan's strategic focus includes fostering collaboration for more effective and sustainable humanitarian CVA, strengthening evidence-based policy and action in order to transform humanitarian CVA and expanding the skills and knowledge required to deliver quality, sustainable humanitarian CVA, at scale.

These include: A feminist approach- To end all forms of discrimination, injustices and violations of rights suffered by women and gender non-conforming people People power – Amplify the voices and actions of people that experience poverty and injustice and work with those who fight for their causes Thinking globally and acting locally- Build a coalition within and between regions and from the local to the global Enhanced humanitarian action- remain committed to delivering life-saving assistance and protection in times of conflict and disaster Digital rights and space- to engage with and leverage the power and influence of digital technology Systematic change – Mobilize to transform the systems that perpetuate poverty and injustice. The strategy also outlines Oxfam’s approach to enhance its humanitarian actions which involves 1) deliveing life-saving support and assistance to communities affected by conflict and disaster, including people on the move; 2) transforming the systems that contribute to fragility and humanitarian crises;3) helping people and communities develop core competencies to strengthen their resilience; 4) continue to reorient the humanitarian system towards local leadership, and; 5) expanding opportunities for those impacted by protracted conflict and recurring crises to lead on sustainable solutions. At the operational level the global strategic framework reaffirms Oxfam’s commitment to humanitarian assistance in the technical areas of WASH, Economic Inclusion, Cash and social protection based approaches, Gender, Community based protection and safe programming, and finally advocacy work to complement programmes in particular on women in conflict. In all the technical areas there are four pillars that will inform the humanitarian approach including 1) Community Engagement; 2) Safe Programming; 3) Partnership and Leadership, 4) Feminist approach. Oxfam is currently working on its Horizon Plan for humanitarian action, which will give practical and pragmatic guidance on expectations for Oxfam countries on its humanitarian ambition, how it is changing in approach and alignment of appropriate support. In 2021/2022 Sida will support Oxfam’s humanitarian interventions in 4 different crises as well as its immediate response to new onset crises or rapidly deteriorating situations through the rapid response mechanisms (RRM). The specific objective of each project might differ, but Oxfam’s core objective within its humanitarian mandate is to work with communities before, during and after crisis to build their resilience, save lives, and together address the root causes of conflict and disaster. Sida will also support a project implemented by Oxfam to improve the use of the Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC) analysis as a tool for ascertaining food insecurity, as well as support to CaLP in order to strengthen the system wide use of CVA as a modality in humanitarian interventions. The following provides a brief description of the projects objectives and intended results: Algeria (10 MSEK) – Refugees from Western Sahara have been living in 5 refugee camps in Tindouf region, southwestern Algeria since 1975 due to an on-going dispute over the control of the Western Sahara Territory. With no imminent political solution to this protracted crisis in sight, the refugee population is largely dependent on external humanitarian aid for its survival. 94% of refugees remain dependent on humanitarian aid as their primary source of support, including for the provision of food, water and other basic needs. The intervention aims to strengthen the resilience amongst 133 672 Sahrawi refugees to meet their basic needs, with a focus on food security and water and sanitation. Food security will be improved through the promotion of local agricultural production and distribution of fresh food during challenging summer months. In line with the official UN 5-year WaSH Strategy and Plan, the piped water network in Boujdour camp (which has relied completely on water trucking to date) will be extended, serving as a model which can later be adapted and scaled up in other camps. Colombia (9 MSEK) - During 2020, refugees and migrants from Venezuela continued arriving in Colombia, with an estimated 1,7 million remaining in the country and half a million in transit to other countries. This situation was further exacerbated by the impact of natural disasters, generalized violence in certain areas, and since March, by the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. This intervention is part of Oxfam´s broad protection strategy to Venezuelan mixed migration flux. It is based on two main components: 1) a strategy to promote sexual and reproductive rights through access to short and medium-term contraceptive methods, accompanied by legal, medical and psychological counselling to manage cases of gender-based violence, and 2) a focused women migrant walkers' program that provides information to tackle risks, reduce vulnerability and strengthen capacities of migrants to avoid risks and mitigate their effects. The project targets approximately 5 000 migrants with protection and NFI assistance. Central African Republic (CAR) (10 MSEK) - Clashes between rebels and government forces in various cities has caused further deterioration of the security situation in CAR since late December 2020, resulting in 105 000 new refugees and 100 000 new IDPs in the beginning of February 2021. The situation affects the sectors of food security; water, hygiene and sanitation; protection and gender, and particularly affects the prefectures of Ouham, Ouham-Pendé and Mbomou in which the project will be implemented. The intervention aims to improve the protection and living conditions of displaced, returnee and host communities in the target areas by strengthening access to food security and livelihoods, improving access to WASH services and building the capacity of affected populations to prevent and respond to protection risks. The project will target approximately 67 000 people across these three areas. In line with Oxfam’s localisation of aid commitments under the Grand Bargain and the Charter for Change, Oxfam will implement this intervention jointly with local humanitarian agencies. Chad (7 MSEK) – Chad is facing three interconnected crises: food insecurity and malnutrition, population movements (481 645 refugees, 336 124 IDPs, and 109 019 new returnees) and health emergencies. The already alarming humanitarian situation in Chad has been further weakened by the suspension of certain humanitarian activities following the implementation of restrictive measures due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The intervention will contribute to the community resilience and self-protection of the displaced populations in the Bagasola and Daboua areas in the Lake region of Chad. It will strengthen IDPs abilities to identify, respond to and mitigate risks and threats to protection. Approximately 40 000 people will be targeted. The project also aims to increase people access to water and sanitation facilities through construction and rehabilitation of waterpoints and improvement of people knowledge and practice of public health and hygiene based on community perceptions. Through cash distribution to highly vulnerable IDPs, returnees and host communities their essential food needs will be met and their livelihoods strengthened. IPC Project in CAR and Zimbabwe (3 MSEK) Specific gaps in country IPC processes have been identified by Oxfam and other stakeholders in Zimbabwe and CAR. Each country has had difficulties with data collection and data quality. In CAR, there are problems with both the quantity and the quality of data available to perform the analyses including a lack of surveys data in some geographic areas and information gaps in the available data (e.g., core food security indicators). In Zimbabwe, the government leads the data collection process and NGOs are invited to participate, but sometimes at short notice and at times with resource contributions to the data collection processes as a prerequisite for participation of agencies in IPC analyses. Large surveys organized by government or UN agencies also tend to crowd out viable sources of information produced by smaller organizations that would otherwise add value and diversity to datasets used in analyses. This interventions is expected to increase the engagement of NGOs (with a goal of at least 4-6 NGOs participating per country) and support expanded plurality in the consensus-building part of the IPC analysis workshop. Greater transparency will be seen through participation of at least two NGO representatives in the full IPC process: pre-analysis (includes primary data collection and preparation), analysis (e.g., workshops), and post-analysis (communication etc.). The project will consolidate one country-based community of practice of agencies involved in IPC per country (CAR and Zimbabwe). CaLP (4 MSEK) The Cash and Voucher Assitance (CVA) landscape is characterized by rapid change and evolving opportunities, both at global and national levels. Technological developments and the changing role of governments, private sector and local actors carry major implications for the role of international humanitarian actors. The amount spent on CVA in humanitarian response has doubled in the past three years. At the same time, overall humanitarian funding has plateaued, meaning that CVA is becoming an increasingly critical part of humanitarian response. The use of CVA has also grown in the COVID-19 response, with the Global Humanitarian Response Plan calling for a scale-up of CVA as an effective way to protect the most vulnerable, as well as reduce the deterioration of assets, livelihoods and social cohesion. The contribution to CaLP will be in support of CaLPs annual plan (2021-2022). The plan's strategic focus includes fostering collaboration for more effective and sustainable humanitarian CVA, strengthening evidence-based policy and action in order to transform humanitarian CVA and expanding the skills and knowledge required to deliver quality, sustainable humanitarian CVA, at scale.

title.narrative: COVID-19 ILO COVID support to women in fason industry
COVID-19 ILO COVID support to women in fason industry

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The proposed intervention will support women in the textile and footwear industry to withstand the negative impacts of the Covid-19 crisis on their livelihood through quick-fix solutions to the financial and economic hardship that they face, via cash transfers in the equivalent of three months minumum salary of 26,000 ALL/month plus 4,342 ALL for social security contributions for 407 women workers, and by promoting a more sustainable solution by preparing the ground for a short-term return to work under safer and improved conditions. The amount to be paid is in line with the GoA measure to cover the wages of the self/employed in micro businesses.
The intervention will develop and disseminate protocols for safe return to work. ILO will facilitate the negotiation of protocols for measures related to the textile and footwear industry and support design of the national guidelines for occupational health and safety measures. Upon preparation of the protocols and guidelines the ILO will provide technical assistance to ensure that companies have an access to recommended safety and health protection measures during the production (protection instruction and reorganization of production protocols) as well as provision of necessary protection equipment and tools that will be distributed to the companies, as set out in the agreed national guidelines. Thus, the intervention will implement Occupational Health Standards and new standard operating procedures in 10 selected factories by securing: • Effective occupational health and safety OSH staff/committees offering guidance to workers, • Putting up signs and posters in the factory that promote good practices on social distancing as well as hygiene and personal protection, • Making sure that the factory is clean and hygienic (including introduction of physical distancing measures in a workplace and use of disinfectants and personal protective equipment). Based on the specific actions planned, the project is expected to have a positive impact on economic recovery and job protection efforts in response to the COVID-19 crisis.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Den föreslagna insatsen omfattar ett kontantstöd till drygt 400 kvinnor i textil- och skoindustrin som drabbats av Covid-19, uppgående till tre månaders minimilön samt att stödja en lösning för att textilarbetare ska kunna återgå i arbete under säkra och förbättrade arbetsförhållanden. Kontantstödet ges i överensstämmelse med den albanska regeringens stöd till anställda i mindre företag.
Insatsen ska bidra till utveckla instruktioner för säkert återvändande till arbetet. ILO ska stödja framtagandet av instruktioner för sko- och textilindustring, vilket bl a omfattar facilitering av diskussioner mellan parter, samt stödja utvecklingen av hälso- och säkerhetsföreskrifter. ILO bidrar med teknisk expertis till företagen så de kan leva upp till dessa föreskrifter samt bidra med skyddsutrustning enligt överenskomna nationella riktlinjer. Insatsen bidrar till genomförande av yrkes- och hälsostandarder för 10 utvalda företag genom att: - Utbilda personal inom arbetsrelaterade hälso- och säkerhetsfrågor på 10 företag; - Tydlig skyltning och annan information på fabriksområdet om vikten av att hålla distans, god hygien och säkerhet; - Stödja god renlighet och hygien på fabrikerna (inklusive införande av rutiner för social distans, användande av skyddsutrustning och disinfektionsmedel etc).
Sammantaget förväntas projektet bidra till en ekonomisk återhämtning och förbättrade arbetsförhållanden efter COVID-19.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Supporting the Vulnerable and Deprived Children in Kosovo
COVID-19 Supporting the Vulnerable and Deprived Children in Kosovo

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Save the Children Sweden has applied to Sida for funding of 1,5 million SEK for "Supporting vulnerable and deprived children with educational and protective/hygienic kits" in rural areas of Kosovo during the period 1 October 2020 until 31 January 2021.
The proposed intervention will focus on approximately 700 families (with approximately 1,400 children and 1,400 adults) who will benefit from educational and protective equipment/hygienic kits directly. These families and children live in remote and rural areas -- including children with disabilities, Roma, Ashkali, and Egyptian children will be supported with didactic and learning materials as well as technological solutions in order to enable access to learning platforms established by the Ministry of Education in cooperation with Save the Children, UNICEF and other partners. These materials, delivered in the form of care and learning packages through a carefully tailored process, will help vulnerable and disadvantaged children to narrow down the “learning gap” with their well-to-do peers. The protective/hygienic packages will enable children and their families to protect themselves and others at home and in the community; it will also support children’s access to classrooms and other learning environments. The Project will organize also awareness-raising activities to inform parents and caretakers – including children – on positive parenting without violence, sharing up-to-date information about COVID-19 and safety precautions, and by empowering them through targeted psycho-social support activities.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Svenska Rädda Barnen söker finansiering från Sida om 1,5 miljoner SEK för att "Stödja utsatta och missgynnade barn med utbildning och skydd/hygienkit" på landsbygden i Kosovo under perioden 1 oktober 2020 till och med 31 januari 2021. Den föreslagna insatsen kommer att fokusera på ca 700 familjer (ca 1400 barn och 1400 vuxna) som kommer att ta del av utbildning och skydd/hygienkit. Insatsen har ett särskilt fokus på barn med funktionsnedsättning. Insatsen kommer att stärka medvetenheten hos föräldrar, vårdnadshavare och barn om positivt föräldraskap utan våld samt relevant information om COVID-19. Mer information i den engelska versionen av beslutet.

title.narrative: Financial Inclusion and technical assistance guarantee

description.narrative: Objectives The overall of objective of the contribution is increased financial inclusion especially for currently excluded groups (MIPYMES with a special focus on women and young) through the introduction and use of a guarantee fund in the sectors of commerce, production and services. The contribution is expected to have the indirect impact to increase the formal economy and financial inclusion contributing to economic development, promote green investments and environmentally sustainable businesses. In parallel the contribution will contribute to the development of new norms in public policy and national financial system that will allow for a more inclusive system with alternative mechanisms developed through the programme. Theory of Change Setting up a guarantee fund, and sharing the risk of lending will increase the lending to other social lenders. With an increased capital and guarantee in the back (with set criteria to incentive that target groups are reached) the social lenders will expand their target group, reach more people and new groups such as more micro and small businesses including women and young as well as increase their knowledge of and hopefully aptitude to lend to these groups in the future. Through the guarantee and TA, PROFIN will promote the innovation of financial products adapted for the target groups and by increasing the access to finance micro and small companies will have a higher probability of surviving and prospering in their business, avoiding to have to go through informal channels with unfavourable conditions. In the long term it is expected that the intervention will increase the formality of the economy and decrease the vulnerability of the micro and small enterprises and with a long term impact of more formal jobs and reduced poverty. To ensure that the goal of increased access reaches the identified target groups and that the micro and small enterprises can make the most of it by having solid business plans and payment plans, a strong component of technical assistance and monitoring must accompany the guarantee. PROFIN, already a partner of the Embassy in the Inclusive markets program, will be responsible and agreement partner to the Embassy in this component. This will include a package of financial education at the loan taker level but also articulation between actors to build knowledge and trust at EIF and institutional level towards the target groups as well as advocacy for inclusive financial legal frameworks at national level. By conditioning the loans to certain environmental and gender standards it is also expected that the intervention will promote a more environmentally sustainable and less discriminatory business climate. PROFIN is well placed to undertake this responsibility with a strong presence in rural areas, trust (at different levels), experience and innovation.

Projektet riktar sig mot den höga informaliteten i den ekonomiska sektorn i Bolivia, den låga nivån av finansiell integration och de svårigheter som mikroföretag och små företag står inför för att få tillgång till finansiering för sin verksamhet. Insatsen syftar parallellt till att bidra till hållbar affärsverksamhet och miljömedvetenhet bland entreprenörer. Projektet ämnar också ha en positiv inverkan på de allvarliga ekonomiska konsekvenserna och svårigheterna för utsatta grupper och entreprenörer i efterdyningarna av COVID 19. Ekonomisk inkludering är ett medel för att uppnå större jämställdhet när det gäller möjligheter och resurser, skapa ekonomiska möjligheter för utsatta grupper och bidra till en hållbar ekonomisk utveckling i Bolivia. Genomförandepartnern föreslås vara PROFIN, en ideell boliviansk organisation, specialiserad på produktiv och ekonomisk utveckling. Programmet är kopplat till planen för att inrätta en garantifond i Bolivia med FOGAL som avtalspartner. För att stödja upprättandet och genomförandet av garantin kommer programmet PROFIN att ge tekniskt stöd. Detta stöd kommer att bestå av olika komponenter inom ramen för det föreslagna projektet såsom; - Finansiell utbildning. PROFIN har lång erfarenhet och kunskap om den finansiella sektorn och målgrupperna för garantin och kommer att arbeta parallellt med att tillhandahålla finansiell utbildning både till familjeproduktionsenheter (UPF) och till finansinstitut angående risker och målgrupper. Detta förväntas leda till ökad tillgång till finansiella tjänster och ökad räckvidd och inkludering av nya målgrupper för de finansiella instituten. -Identifiera och utveckla en finansiell mekanism/uppföljningssystem för att bidra till genomförandet av Agenda 2030 -Studie av det rättsliga systemet i Bolivia för inrättande av FOGAL-landskontor, förespråkande och studier för att ge råd och påverka lagar och normer som begränsar de nuvarande finansiella systemen. -PROFIN kommer att ge stöd till FOGAL i etablerandet av partnerskapskontrakt med lokala finansinstitut. -Övervakning och uppföljning av lån PROFIN kommer att implementera ett uppföljningssystem som rör målen för hållbar utveckling och kommer också att utforska nya finansieringsverktyg och metoder. Projektet kommer att löpa över fem år med en total budget på 9 012 598SEK. Sidas bidrag föreslås i första hand finansiera de första tre åren av projektet med en budget på 5 991 917 SEK. Projektet kommer att börja med en startfas för att anpassa och justera förslaget till en baslinje och till den ekonomiska och politiska situationen.

The contribution is targeting the high informality of the economic sector in Bolivia, the low level of financial inclusion and the difficulties micro and small enterprises faces to access finance for their business. The intervention is in parallel aiming to contribute to sustainable businesses and environmental consciousness among entrepreneurs. The intervention is also responding to the severe economic consequences and difficulties vulnerable groups and entrepreneurs phases in the aftermaths of COVID 19. The Embassy assess that financial inclusion is a mean to achieve a greater equality in terms of opportunities and resources, creating financial opportunities for vulnerable groups and contribute to a sustainable economic development in Bolivia. The implementing partner is proposed to be PROFIN, a non profit Bolivian organisation specialized in productive and financial development. The project is connected to the plan of setting up a guarantee fund in Bolivia with FOGAL as the contractual partner. To support the set up and the implementation of the guarantee PROFIN will be providing Technical Assistance through this proposed project. This assistance will consist of different components such as; - Financial education. PROFIN has long experience and knowledge of the financial sector and the target groups of the guarantee and will work in parallel to provide financial education both to Family Production Units (UPFs) and to financial institutions regarding risks and target groups. This is expected to result in a greater access and a greater use of financing from financial entities, -Identify and develop financial mechanism/reporting system to contribute to the fulfillment of Agenda 2030 -study of the legal system in Bolivia for the set up of FOGAL country office, advocacy and studies to provide advice and influence the laws and norms limiting the current financial systems. -PROFIN will accompany FOGAL in seeking partnerships-contracts with local financial institutions. -Monitoring and follow up of loans PROFIN will implement a monitoring system relating to the Sustainable development goals and will also be exploring new financing tools and methods. The project is proposed to run over five years with a budget of approximately 10 MSEK. Sida is proposed to initially fund the first three years with a total budget of 5 991 917 SEK. The project will start with an inception phase in order to adjust and adapt the proposal to a baseline and to the changes economic and political situation.
