description.narrative: FSD Kenya’s projects are organised into four areas based on the financial market development outcomes outlined in its theory of change. These are: (i) Long-term vision and policy, (ii) Regulation, (iii) Financial infrastructure, and (iv) Innovation. Progress in each area and the crosscutting functions are described below. Projects under long term vision and policy included recent FSDK technical support led to the creation of a new Kenya Government Digital economy strategy blueprint (2019) launched by the Kenyan president and the recognition of Digital Finance as a flagship project highlighting the importance of the financial sector development policy (from 2005) to formally encompass financial access as a policy priority alongside efficiency and stability. A trusted partner of the National Treasury, FSD Kenya has been directly engaged in the development of successive Vision 2030 medium-term plans for the financial services sector. FSD Kenya initiated the first comprehensive market survey on financial inclusion (FinAccess Household Survey report) and supported it to becoming a sustainable part of the government statistical architecture, the study which has become the most valuable financial inclusion tracking instrument is jointly done every three years by FSDK, Central Bank of Kenya and Kenya National Bureau of Statistics . Kenya continues to be considered at the frontier in Africa, particularly given the scale and role of mobile money and fintech in both driving financial inclusion but also creating new areas of concern. Market information built on the success of the FinAccess household survey report 2019 launch garnered support for sustainability and use of FinAccess as well as the potential to complement this with the supply side data intervention. Other several successful events were held highlighting the value of segmentation and how to use data to develop more inclusive financial solutions. Under the Regulatory system development, the interest rate controls introduced in September 2016 were abolished in 2019, which is expected to have a positive impact on credit growth especially with regard to micro and small medium enterprises access to finance, financial integration and tax revenues. Additionally, work on regulation by FSD Kenya helped establish the new enabling regulatory frameworks which have underpinned the expansion of financial inclusion and fintech innovation in Kenya. This has included regulation for deposit-taking microfinance and financial co-operatives, the regulatory response which enabled the emergence of the M-Pesa mobile-money platform, agent banking, electronic payments and the first regulatory sandbox for fintech in Kenya (under the Capital Markets Authority). Under stability, the Capital Markets Authority (CMA) Sandbox continues to progress well and has inspired a promising conversation at the annual joint financial sector regulators forum about a sector-wide approach to innovation. Competition work has resulted in enhanced disclosure in both digital and non-digital realms. Reflecting Kenya’s success in encouraging the development of digital finance, regulators from across the continent and beyond have sought to learn from the Kenya approach facilitated by FSD Kenya in collaboration with the FSD Network. FinAccess Household Survey report 2019 revealed that mobile money users have substantially more challenges than users of regulated financial services like banks and mobile banks, with nearly 30% experiencing loss of money or fraud. Thus, Kenya’s financial stability is linked to innovation both in the financial sector and more broadly. The results of this work are clearly evident in the 2019 Financial Access Household Survey, where formal financial inclusion has risen from 26.7% of adults in 2006 to 82.9% in 2019, while complete exclusion of financial access and services has dropped from 41.3% of adults in 2006 to 11.0% in 2019. The informal financial sector declined from 32.1% in 2006 to 6.1% in 2019; the “excluded” category – the “unbankable” – declined from 41.3% in 2006 to 11% in 2019. PWC’s Africa Business Agenda 2019 indicated that Kenya is number 1 in Africa in the growth of innovative companies. A key area of focus going forward in Kenya will be to drive for financial stability and market integrity particularly with regards market conduct, while supporting financial innovation that drives inclusive growth. Significant gains have been achieved in improving financial infrastructure. FSD Kenya was involved in the inception of credit information sharing which now encompasses most of the formal financial system although more work is needed as credit markets continue to evolve. So far there are atleast three credit Reference Bureaus ( Credit Reference Bureau Africa Limited, Metropol Credit Reference Bureau limited and Creditinfo Credit Reference Bureau Kenya Ltd) licensed by the Central Bank of Kenya to collect and collate credit information on individuals and businesses from different sources and provide that information upon request mainly by credit providers in the form of a credit report. Support for interoperability in the payments system resulted in the creation of a new proto-national switch by the Kenya Bankers Association which has already resulted in market price improvements. This has for example resulted in scaling up of the interbank money transfer solution (PesaLink), which has moved Kenya further toward a cashless society with more financial inclusivity. FSD Kenya pioneered the use of the financial sector to deliver social protection payments in Kenya through support of the UKAid initiated Hunger Safety Net Programme and used that experience to support the launch of the government’s Inua Jamii programme in 2005 now supporting 1.2m low-income beneficiaries. Inua Jamii is owned by the Government and last year 2019 saw the close-out of Hunger Safety Net Programme (HSNP) and the government fully taking charge of the social protection programmes. Payment platforms picked up speed with progress on the National Payments System Strategy, filling key positions at Integrated Payment Services Limited (IPSL) and the Payments Association of Kenya (PAK), and initiating new work on the cash-digital interface. Aside from closing out HSNP, the rest of the Government payments work is progressing well on biometric standard interoperability, support to the Government Digital Payments (GDP) team and the ongoing support to Inua Jamii. Under Innovations, Trade facilitation and Building livelihoods both had strong progress in 2019 while the Financial innovations for the real economy (FIRE) project was on track with existing activities but behind plan on new work. The Trade project which is a public private development partnership with Kenya National Chamber of Commerce and Industry (KNCCI), Export Promotion and Brand Kenya (BrandKe), the technology provider Retail Pay Limited and the agreement partner FSDK, witnessed the full launch of the RetailPay pilot, which is a transparent system to facilitate trade end-to-end and operational support as well as key interventions initiated with consortium partners. Significant activity is underway with the Marsabit graduation pilot. The programme was initiated with the aim of testing market-based approaches to building livelihoods of very poor people; and to develop an understanding of how effectively link graduation support with market development in order to increase income and resilience among very poor households in Marsabit County, Northern Kenya. Initial results from the field monitoring visit to Marsabit (see field vist report) reveal a more positive picture about the impact of the graduation work and call into question whether the project should be closed this year or extended to ensure full sustainability. Generally, Innovation has been a centrepiece of the FSD Kenya programme from the outset and today Kenya is positioned globally as a leading innovator in financial inclusion and fintech. Direct support for the development of the Commercial Bank of Africa (CBA)/M-Pesa M-Shwari digital savings and credit solution (25.8m accounts opened since inception) has resulted in highly competitive market for digital finance. This solution has been replicated in many additional markets across Africa and beyond. Investment in establishing a novel shared management services network for 38 financial services associations (village banks) serving 300,000 low-income rural households most with no access to the formal financial service providers (except M-Pesa). FSD Kenya helped created new models to scale-up improved community-based savings groups – currently used by over one million poor households in Kenya. This work has been leveraged by other FSDs in Mozambique and Zambia. More recent work has supported experimentation with fintechs working at the intersection of finance and real-economy areas like agriculture and health. FSD Kenya’s cross-cutting functions continue to support the programme effectively. Building on the full roll-out of the project data management system, the results function supported the projects to ensure activity is aligned with objectives. Beyond the system, Results also engaged with the FSD Network process of aligning indicators on impact, carried out internal reviews through field visits and facilitated a new cross-project effort to generate case studies on the sustainability of FSD’s impact. FSD Kenya has solidified its position as the go-to source of information on financial inclusion in Kenya. In the third quarter alone of 2019, there were 62 mentions of FSD Kenya’s work in the press, 7 blogs published by the team (including one turned into an Op-ed at the request of one of the leading main stream newspapers in Kenya -Daily Nation) and increased social media engagement. According to the World Bank, it has become much easier to do business in Kenya and Kenya’s robust digital economy is mentioned as the most significant contributor to this success. In the Bank's Ease of Doing Business Index, Kenya ranked 61 out of 190 countries in 2019, up from 136 in 2015
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The Financial Sector Deepening (FSDK) Program is a multi-donor programme operating in Kenya through a Trust association modality. FSDK was established to facilitate the development of the financial sector and to increase the access for poor people to financial services in Kenya. FSDK Strategy 2016-2021 goal is “to generate sustainable improvements in the lives of lower-income people in Kenya” which entail seeking opportunities which build resilience, growth and improvement in quality of life for the low-income Groups. The specific objective is “to develop a financial system which delivers real value to the low-income people in Kenya”. This will be articulated through working with market players to address three key barriers to inclusion including: 1. High cost; 2. Insufficient value; and 3. Weak trust. Key approach to attainment of this is building capacity for the market to address market barriers and innovate solutions for real world needs of poor people and businesses by addressing market challenges (outcomes) which include: rules of the game (which shift incentives in favour of the poor); enhancing efficiencies in the industry infrastructure; and promoting a shared collective vision on development of the Financial Services Sector.
The revised budgetary requirement following DFID exit from support to core Financial Inclusion programme is BKES 3.188 out of which BKES 1.622 has already been secured from Gates Foundation and BKES 1.086 is a carryover from previous strategy support (as at January 2017). Sweden is requested to provide BKES 0.48 (MSEK 50).

The intervention has two components namely financial inclusion and trade facilitation. The intended outcome is to generate sustainable improvements in the lives of lower-income people in Kenya through development of a financial and trade system which delivers real value to the low-income people in Kenya. The objectives of this intervention; both financial inclusion and trade facilitation is anchored on working with market players to address three key bariers to inclusion namely i) high cost;ii) insufficient value; and iii) weak trust in the system While the specific approach to attainment of these objectives of reducing costs, creating value and building trust in both the financial and trade market system relies on building the capacity of the market to work with key areas including: rules of the game which shift incentives in favour of the poor; enhancing efficiencies in the industry infrastructure; and promoting a shared collective vision on development of the financial services sector (FSS). Additionally, trade facilitation for the real economy aims at creating market capacity and incentives to innovate trade solutions which deliver real value for the economy, enterprises and households. The rationale behind the trade facilitation is that the trade system must evolve in a way that it only allocates value to trading partners in line with the value they have added within the system and by breaking down information asymmetries.

description.narrative: FSD Kenya’s projects are organised into four areas based on the financial market development outcomes outlined in its theory of change. These are: (i) Long-term vision and policy, (ii) Regulation, (iii) Financial infrastructure, and (iv) Innovation. Progress in each area and the crosscutting functions are described below. Projects under long term vision and policy included recent FSDK technical support led to the creation of a new Kenya Government Digital economy strategy blueprint (2019) launched by the Kenyan president and the recognition of Digital Finance as a flagship project highlighting the importance of the financial sector development policy (from 2005) to formally encompass financial access as a policy priority alongside efficiency and stability. A trusted partner of the National Treasury, FSD Kenya has been directly engaged in the development of successive Vision 2030 medium-term plans for the financial services sector. FSD Kenya initiated the first comprehensive market survey on financial inclusion (FinAccess Household Survey report) and supported it to becoming a sustainable part of the government statistical architecture, the study which has become the most valuable financial inclusion tracking instrument is jointly done every three years by FSDK, Central Bank of Kenya and Kenya National Bureau of Statistics . Kenya continues to be considered at the frontier in Africa, particularly given the scale and role of mobile money and fintech in both driving financial inclusion but also creating new areas of concern. Market information built on the success of the FinAccess household survey report 2019 launch garnered support for sustainability and use of FinAccess as well as the potential to complement this with the supply side data intervention. Other several successful events were held highlighting the value of segmentation and how to use data to develop more inclusive financial solutions. Under the Regulatory system development, the interest rate controls introduced in September 2016 were abolished in 2019, which is expected to have a positive impact on credit growth especially with regard to micro and small medium enterprises access to finance, financial integration and tax revenues. Additionally, work on regulation by FSD Kenya helped establish the new enabling regulatory frameworks which have underpinned the expansion of financial inclusion and fintech innovation in Kenya. This has included regulation for deposit-taking microfinance and financial co-operatives, the regulatory response which enabled the emergence of the M-Pesa mobile-money platform, agent banking, electronic payments and the first regulatory sandbox for fintech in Kenya (under the Capital Markets Authority). Under stability, the Capital Markets Authority (CMA) Sandbox continues to progress well and has inspired a promising conversation at the annual joint financial sector regulators forum about a sector-wide approach to innovation. Competition work has resulted in enhanced disclosure in both digital and non-digital realms. Reflecting Kenya’s success in encouraging the development of digital finance, regulators from across the continent and beyond have sought to learn from the Kenya approach facilitated by FSD Kenya in collaboration with the FSD Network. FinAccess Household Survey report 2019 revealed that mobile money users have substantially more challenges than users of regulated financial services like banks and mobile banks, with nearly 30% experiencing loss of money or fraud. Thus, Kenya’s financial stability is linked to innovation both in the financial sector and more broadly. The results of this work are clearly evident in the 2019 Financial Access Household Survey, where formal financial inclusion has risen from 26.7% of adults in 2006 to 82.9% in 2019, while complete exclusion of financial access and services has dropped from 41.3% of adults in 2006 to 11.0% in 2019. The informal financial sector declined from 32.1% in 2006 to 6.1% in 2019; the “excluded” category – the “unbankable” – declined from 41.3% in 2006 to 11% in 2019. PWC’s Africa Business Agenda 2019 indicated that Kenya is number 1 in Africa in the growth of innovative companies. A key area of focus going forward in Kenya will be to drive for financial stability and market integrity particularly with regards market conduct, while supporting financial innovation that drives inclusive growth. Significant gains have been achieved in improving financial infrastructure. FSD Kenya was involved in the inception of credit information sharing which now encompasses most of the formal financial system although more work is needed as credit markets continue to evolve. So far there are atleast three credit Reference Bureaus ( Credit Reference Bureau Africa Limited, Metropol Credit Reference Bureau limited and Creditinfo Credit Reference Bureau Kenya Ltd) licensed by the Central Bank of Kenya to collect and collate credit information on individuals and businesses from different sources and provide that information upon request mainly by credit providers in the form of a credit report. Support for interoperability in the payments system resulted in the creation of a new proto-national switch by the Kenya Bankers Association which has already resulted in market price improvements. This has for example resulted in scaling up of the interbank money transfer solution (PesaLink), which has moved Kenya further toward a cashless society with more financial inclusivity. FSD Kenya pioneered the use of the financial sector to deliver social protection payments in Kenya through support of the UKAid initiated Hunger Safety Net Programme and used that experience to support the launch of the government’s Inua Jamii programme in 2005 now supporting 1.2m low-income beneficiaries. Inua Jamii is owned by the Government and last year 2019 saw the close-out of Hunger Safety Net Programme (HSNP) and the government fully taking charge of the social protection programmes. Payment platforms picked up speed with progress on the National Payments System Strategy, filling key positions at Integrated Payment Services Limited (IPSL) and the Payments Association of Kenya (PAK), and initiating new work on the cash-digital interface. Aside from closing out HSNP, the rest of the Government payments work is progressing well on biometric standard interoperability, support to the Government Digital Payments (GDP) team and the ongoing support to Inua Jamii. Under Innovations, Trade facilitation and Building livelihoods both had strong progress in 2019 while the Financial innovations for the real economy (FIRE) project was on track with existing activities but behind plan on new work. The Trade project which is a public private development partnership with Kenya National Chamber of Commerce and Industry (KNCCI), Export Promotion and Brand Kenya (BrandKe), the technology provider Retail Pay Limited and the agreement partner FSDK, witnessed the full launch of the RetailPay pilot, which is a transparent system to facilitate trade end-to-end and operational support as well as key interventions initiated with consortium partners. Significant activity is underway with the Marsabit graduation pilot. The programme was initiated with the aim of testing market-based approaches to building livelihoods of very poor people; and to develop an understanding of how effectively link graduation support with market development in order to increase income and resilience among very poor households in Marsabit County, Northern Kenya. Initial results from the field monitoring visit to Marsabit (see field vist report) reveal a more positive picture about the impact of the graduation work and call into question whether the project should be closed this year or extended to ensure full sustainability. Generally, Innovation has been a centrepiece of the FSD Kenya programme from the outset and today Kenya is positioned globally as a leading innovator in financial inclusion and fintech. Direct support for the development of the Commercial Bank of Africa (CBA)/M-Pesa M-Shwari digital savings and credit solution (25.8m accounts opened since inception) has resulted in highly competitive market for digital finance. This solution has been replicated in many additional markets across Africa and beyond. Investment in establishing a novel shared management services network for 38 financial services associations (village banks) serving 300,000 low-income rural households most with no access to the formal financial service providers (except M-Pesa). FSD Kenya helped created new models to scale-up improved community-based savings groups – currently used by over one million poor households in Kenya. This work has been leveraged by other FSDs in Mozambique and Zambia. More recent work has supported experimentation with fintechs working at the intersection of finance and real-economy areas like agriculture and health. FSD Kenya’s cross-cutting functions continue to support the programme effectively. Building on the full roll-out of the project data management system, the results function supported the projects to ensure activity is aligned with objectives. Beyond the system, Results also engaged with the FSD Network process of aligning indicators on impact, carried out internal reviews through field visits and facilitated a new cross-project effort to generate case studies on the sustainability of FSD’s impact. FSD Kenya has solidified its position as the go-to source of information on financial inclusion in Kenya. In the third quarter alone of 2019, there were 62 mentions of FSD Kenya’s work in the press, 7 blogs published by the team (including one turned into an Op-ed at the request of one of the leading main stream newspapers in Kenya -Daily Nation) and increased social media engagement. According to the World Bank, it has become much easier to do business in Kenya and Kenya’s robust digital economy is mentioned as the most significant contributor to this success. In the Bank's Ease of Doing Business Index, Kenya ranked 61 out of 190 countries in 2019, up from 136 in 2015
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Financial Sector Deepening Program (FSDK) finansieras gemensamt av flera givare och verkar i Kenya via en stiftelse, eller Trust. FSDK etablerades för att befrämja en utveckling av finanssektorn samt för öka fattiga människors tillgång till finansiella tjänster i Kenya. FSDK:s strategimål för 2016-2021 är att "åstadkomma varaktiga förbättringar av kenyanska låginkomsttagares levnadsförhållanden". I detta ingår att hitta möjligheter att skapa resiliens, hållbarhet och förbättrade levnadsförhållanden för låginkomsttagare. Det specifika målet är att "utveckla ett finansiellt system som skapar ett verkligt värde för låginkomsttagare i Kenya". Detta ska ske genom att samarbeta med marknadsaktörer i syfte att undanröja de hinder som finns för ett inkluderande system: 1. Hög kostnad; 2. otillräckligt värde; och 3. lågt förtroende. För att åstadkomma detta vill man bygga upp kapacitet hos aktörerna så att de kan arbeta för att undanröja hinder och hitta innovativa lösningar som kommer fattiga människor och företag till del. I detta ingår att: ändra spelreglerna och öka incitamenten för att gynna fattiga; förbättra effektiviteten inom branschen; samt befrämja en samsyn om finanssektorns utveckling.
Den reviderade budgeten, efter att DFID avbrutit sitt stöd till programmet Financial Inclusion, uppgår till 3,188 miljarder KES, varav 1,622 miljarder KES redan säkrats av Gates Foundation och 1,086 miljarder KES överförts från tidigare strategistöd (i januari 2017). Sverige ombeds bidra med 0,48 miljarder KES (50 MSEK).

tag.narrative: 1.a - Ensure significant mobilization of resources from a variety of sources, including through enhanced development cooperation, in order to provide adequate and predictable means for developing countries, in particular least developed countries, to implement programmes and policies to end poverty in all its dimensions.

1.a - Säkra en betydande resursmobilisering från en mängd olika källor, inklusive genom ökat utvecklingssamarbete, i syfte att ge utvecklingsländerna, i synnerhet de minst utvecklade länderna, tillräckliga och förutsebara medel för att genomföra program och politik för att avskaffa all form av fattigdom.

1.b - Create sound policy frameworks at the national, regional and international levels, based on pro-poor and gender-sensitive development strategies, to support accelerated investment in poverty eradication actions.

1.b - Upprätta sunda policyramverk på nationell, regional och internationell nivå på grundval av utvecklingsstrategier som stödjer de fattiga och tar hänsyn till jämställdhetsaspekter, för att stödja ökade investeringar i åtgärder för att avskaffa fattigdom.

2.3 - By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and non-farm employment.

2.3 - Till 2030 fördubbla jordbrukets produktivitet och inkomster för småskaliga livsmedelsproducenter, i synnerhet kvinnor, ursprungsfolk, familjejordbrukare, boskapsskötande nomader samt fiskare, inklusive genom säker och lika tillgång till mark, andra produktionsresurser och insatsvaror, kunskap, finansiella tjänster och marknader samt möjligheter till värdeskapande och sysselsättning utanför jordbruket.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.
5.b - Enhance the use of enabling technology, in particular information and communications technology, to promote the empowerment of women.
5.b - Öka användningen av gynnsam teknik, i synnerhet informations- och kommunikationsteknik, för att främja kvinnors egenmakt
5.c - Adopt and strengthen sound policies and enforceable legislation for the promotion of gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls at all levels.
5.c - Anta och stärka välgrundad politik och genomförbar lagstiftning för att främja jämställdhet och öka alla kvinnors och flickors egenmakt på alla nivåer
8.10 - Strengthen the capacity of domestic financial institutions to encourage and expand access to banking, insurance and financial services for all.
8.10 - Stärka de inhemska finansinstitutens kapacitet att främja och utöka tillgången till bank- och försäkringstjänster samt finansiella tjänster för alla.

8.3 - Främja utvecklingsinriktad politik som stöder produktiv verksamhet, skapande av anständiga arbetstillfällen, företagande, kreativitet och innovation samt uppmuntra att mikroföretag liksom små och medelstora företag växer och blir en del av den formella ekonomin, bland annat genom tillgång till finansiella tjänster.

8.3 - Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.

9.3 - Increase the access of small-scale industrial and other enterprises, in particular in developing countries, to financial services, including affordable credit, and their integration into value chains and markets.

9.3 - Öka tillgången för småskaliga industriföretag och andra företag, i synnerhet i utvecklingsländerna, till finansiella tjänster, inklusive överkomliga krediter, samt deras integrering i värdekedjor och marknader.

9.b - Stödja inhemsk teknikutveckling, forskning och innovation i utvecklingsländerna, inklusive genom att säkerställa en gynnsam policymiljö för exempelvis industriell diversifiering och förädling av råvaror.

9.b - Support domestic technology development, research and innovation in developing countries, including by ensuring a conducive policy environment for, inter alia, industrial diversification and value addition to commodities.

FSDK etablerades för att befrämja en utveckling av finanssektorn samt för öka fattiga människors tillgång till finansiella tjänster i Kenya. FSDK:s strategimål för 2016-2021 är att "åstadkomma varaktiga förbättringar av kenyanska låginkomsttagares levnadsförhållanden". I detta ingår att hitta möjligheter att skapa resiliens, hållbarhet och förbättrade levnadsförhållanden för låginkomsttagare. Det specifika målet är att "utveckla ett finansiellt system som skapar ett verkligt värde för låginkomsttagare i Kenya". Detta ska ske genom att samarbeta med marknadsaktörer i syfte att undanröja de hinder som finns för ett inkluderande system: 1. Hög kostnad; 2. otillräckligt värde; och 3. lågt förtroende. För att åstadkomma detta vill man bygga upp kapacitet hos aktörerna så att de kan arbeta för att undanröja hinder och hitta innovativa lösningar som kommer fattiga människor och företag till del. I detta ingår att: ändra spelreglerna och öka incitamenten för att gynna fattiga; förbättra effektiviteten inom branschen; samt befrämja en samsyn om finanssektorns utveckling.
Den reviderade budgeten, efter att DFID avbrutit sitt stöd till programmet Financial Inclusion, uppgår till 3,188 miljarder KES, varav 1,622 miljarder KES redan säkrats av Gates Foundation och 1,086 miljarder KES överförts från tidigare strategistöd (i januari 2017). Sverige ombeds bidra med 0,48 miljarder KES (50 MSEK).

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The Financial Sector Deepening (FSDK) Program is a multi-donor programme operating in Kenya through a Trust association modality. FSDK was established to facilitate the development of the financial sector and to increase the access for poor people to financial services in Kenya. FSDK Strategy 2016-2021 goal is “to generate sustainable improvements in the lives of lower-income people in Kenya” which entail seeking opportunities which build resilience, growth and improvement in quality of life for the low-income Groups. The specific objective is “to develop a financial system which delivers real value to the low-income people in Kenya”. This will be articulated through working with market players to address three key barriers to inclusion including: 1. High cost; 2. Insufficient value; and 3. Weak trust. Key approach to attainment of this is building capacity for the market to address market barriers and innovate solutions for real world needs of poor people and businesses by addressing market challenges (outcomes) which include: rules of the game (which shift incentives in favour of the poor); enhancing efficiencies in the industry infrastructure; and promoting a shared collective vision on development of the Financial Services Sector.
The revised budgetary requirement following DFID exit from support to core Financial Inclusion programme is BKES 3.188 out of which BKES 1.622 has already been secured from Gates Foundation and BKES 1.086 is a carryover from previous strategy support (as at January 2017). Sweden is requested to provide BKES 0.48 (MSEK 50).

The intervention has two components namely financial inclusion and trade facilitation. The intended outcome is to generate sustainable improvements in the lives of lower-income people in Kenya through development of a financial and trade system which delivers real value to the low-income people in Kenya. The objectives of this intervention; both financial inclusion and trade facilitation is anchored on working with market players to address three key bariers to inclusion namely i) high cost;ii) insufficient value; and iii) weak trust in the system While the specific approach to attainment of these objectives of reducing costs, creating value and building trust in both the financial and trade market system relies on building the capacity of the market to work with key areas including: rules of the game which shift incentives in favour of the poor; enhancing efficiencies in the industry infrastructure; and promoting a shared collective vision on development of the financial services sector (FSS). Additionally, trade facilitation for the real economy aims at creating market capacity and incentives to innovate trade solutions which deliver real value for the economy, enterprises and households. The rationale behind the trade facilitation is that the trade system must evolve in a way that it only allocates value to trading partners in line with the value they have added within the system and by breaking down information asymmetries.

description.narrative: FSD Kenya’s projects are organised into four areas based on the financial market development outcomes outlined in its theory of change. These are: (i) Long-term vision and policy, (ii) Regulation, (iii) Financial infrastructure, and (iv) Innovation. Progress in each area and the crosscutting functions are described below. Projects under long term vision and policy included recent FSDK technical support led to the creation of a new Kenya Government Digital economy strategy blueprint (2019) launched by the Kenyan president and the recognition of Digital Finance as a flagship project highlighting the importance of the financial sector development policy (from 2005) to formally encompass financial access as a policy priority alongside efficiency and stability. A trusted partner of the National Treasury, FSD Kenya has been directly engaged in the development of successive Vision 2030 medium-term plans for the financial services sector. FSD Kenya initiated the first comprehensive market survey on financial inclusion (FinAccess Household Survey report) and supported it to becoming a sustainable part of the government statistical architecture, the study which has become the most valuable financial inclusion tracking instrument is jointly done every three years by FSDK, Central Bank of Kenya and Kenya National Bureau of Statistics . Kenya continues to be considered at the frontier in Africa, particularly given the scale and role of mobile money and fintech in both driving financial inclusion but also creating new areas of concern. Market information built on the success of the FinAccess household survey report 2019 launch garnered support for sustainability and use of FinAccess as well as the potential to complement this with the supply side data intervention. Other several successful events were held highlighting the value of segmentation and how to use data to develop more inclusive financial solutions. Under the Regulatory system development, the interest rate controls introduced in September 2016 were abolished in 2019, which is expected to have a positive impact on credit growth especially with regard to micro and small medium enterprises access to finance, financial integration and tax revenues. Additionally, work on regulation by FSD Kenya helped establish the new enabling regulatory frameworks which have underpinned the expansion of financial inclusion and fintech innovation in Kenya. This has included regulation for deposit-taking microfinance and financial co-operatives, the regulatory response which enabled the emergence of the M-Pesa mobile-money platform, agent banking, electronic payments and the first regulatory sandbox for fintech in Kenya (under the Capital Markets Authority). Under stability, the Capital Markets Authority (CMA) Sandbox continues to progress well and has inspired a promising conversation at the annual joint financial sector regulators forum about a sector-wide approach to innovation. Competition work has resulted in enhanced disclosure in both digital and non-digital realms. Reflecting Kenya’s success in encouraging the development of digital finance, regulators from across the continent and beyond have sought to learn from the Kenya approach facilitated by FSD Kenya in collaboration with the FSD Network. FinAccess Household Survey report 2019 revealed that mobile money users have substantially more challenges than users of regulated financial services like banks and mobile banks, with nearly 30% experiencing loss of money or fraud. Thus, Kenya’s financial stability is linked to innovation both in the financial sector and more broadly. The results of this work are clearly evident in the 2019 Financial Access Household Survey, where formal financial inclusion has risen from 26.7% of adults in 2006 to 82.9% in 2019, while complete exclusion of financial access and services has dropped from 41.3% of adults in 2006 to 11.0% in 2019. The informal financial sector declined from 32.1% in 2006 to 6.1% in 2019; the “excluded” category – the “unbankable” – declined from 41.3% in 2006 to 11% in 2019. PWC’s Africa Business Agenda 2019 indicated that Kenya is number 1 in Africa in the growth of innovative companies. A key area of focus going forward in Kenya will be to drive for financial stability and market integrity particularly with regards market conduct, while supporting financial innovation that drives inclusive growth. Significant gains have been achieved in improving financial infrastructure. FSD Kenya was involved in the inception of credit information sharing which now encompasses most of the formal financial system although more work is needed as credit markets continue to evolve. So far there are atleast three credit Reference Bureaus ( Credit Reference Bureau Africa Limited, Metropol Credit Reference Bureau limited and Creditinfo Credit Reference Bureau Kenya Ltd) licensed by the Central Bank of Kenya to collect and collate credit information on individuals and businesses from different sources and provide that information upon request mainly by credit providers in the form of a credit report. Support for interoperability in the payments system resulted in the creation of a new proto-national switch by the Kenya Bankers Association which has already resulted in market price improvements. This has for example resulted in scaling up of the interbank money transfer solution (PesaLink), which has moved Kenya further toward a cashless society with more financial inclusivity. FSD Kenya pioneered the use of the financial sector to deliver social protection payments in Kenya through support of the UKAid initiated Hunger Safety Net Programme and used that experience to support the launch of the government’s Inua Jamii programme in 2005 now supporting 1.2m low-income beneficiaries. Inua Jamii is owned by the Government and last year 2019 saw the close-out of Hunger Safety Net Programme (HSNP) and the government fully taking charge of the social protection programmes. Payment platforms picked up speed with progress on the National Payments System Strategy, filling key positions at Integrated Payment Services Limited (IPSL) and the Payments Association of Kenya (PAK), and initiating new work on the cash-digital interface. Aside from closing out HSNP, the rest of the Government payments work is progressing well on biometric standard interoperability, support to the Government Digital Payments (GDP) team and the ongoing support to Inua Jamii. Under Innovations, Trade facilitation and Building livelihoods both had strong progress in 2019 while the Financial innovations for the real economy (FIRE) project was on track with existing activities but behind plan on new work. The Trade project which is a public private development partnership with Kenya National Chamber of Commerce and Industry (KNCCI), Export Promotion and Brand Kenya (BrandKe), the technology provider Retail Pay Limited and the agreement partner FSDK, witnessed the full launch of the RetailPay pilot, which is a transparent system to facilitate trade end-to-end and operational support as well as key interventions initiated with consortium partners. Significant activity is underway with the Marsabit graduation pilot. The programme was initiated with the aim of testing market-based approaches to building livelihoods of very poor people; and to develop an understanding of how effectively link graduation support with market development in order to increase income and resilience among very poor households in Marsabit County, Northern Kenya. Initial results from the field monitoring visit to Marsabit (see field vist report) reveal a more positive picture about the impact of the graduation work and call into question whether the project should be closed this year or extended to ensure full sustainability. Generally, Innovation has been a centrepiece of the FSD Kenya programme from the outset and today Kenya is positioned globally as a leading innovator in financial inclusion and fintech. Direct support for the development of the Commercial Bank of Africa (CBA)/M-Pesa M-Shwari digital savings and credit solution (25.8m accounts opened since inception) has resulted in highly competitive market for digital finance. This solution has been replicated in many additional markets across Africa and beyond. Investment in establishing a novel shared management services network for 38 financial services associations (village banks) serving 300,000 low-income rural households most with no access to the formal financial service providers (except M-Pesa). FSD Kenya helped created new models to scale-up improved community-based savings groups – currently used by over one million poor households in Kenya. This work has been leveraged by other FSDs in Mozambique and Zambia. More recent work has supported experimentation with fintechs working at the intersection of finance and real-economy areas like agriculture and health. FSD Kenya’s cross-cutting functions continue to support the programme effectively. Building on the full roll-out of the project data management system, the results function supported the projects to ensure activity is aligned with objectives. Beyond the system, Results also engaged with the FSD Network process of aligning indicators on impact, carried out internal reviews through field visits and facilitated a new cross-project effort to generate case studies on the sustainability of FSD’s impact. FSD Kenya has solidified its position as the go-to source of information on financial inclusion in Kenya. In the third quarter alone of 2019, there were 62 mentions of FSD Kenya’s work in the press, 7 blogs published by the team (including one turned into an Op-ed at the request of one of the leading main stream newspapers in Kenya -Daily Nation) and increased social media engagement. According to the World Bank, it has become much easier to do business in Kenya and Kenya’s robust digital economy is mentioned as the most significant contributor to this success. In the Bank's Ease of Doing Business Index, Kenya ranked 61 out of 190 countries in 2019, up from 136 in 2015

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 FN:s WFP och UNICEF har lämnat ett gemensamt programförslag till Sverige gällande ett stöd på totalt 78 MSEK till den kenyanska staten. Syftet är att bygga upp ett system som ger rättvis tillgång till sociala skyddssystem och barnskyddssystem.
Den långsiktiga visionen är ett socialt skyddssystem som är integrerat, tar hänsyn till barn och fungerar i nödsituationer, som ger förmånstagarna tillgång till ett grundläggande socialt skydd samt att ett ökat antal män, kvinnor, pojkar och flickor från de fattigaste och mest sårbara hushållen får tillgång till detta.
Förslaget går ut på att ge teknisk assistans vid revidering, utveckling och införande av lagar, rutiner och strategier gällande socialt skydd och barnskydd, att förstärka system, öka kapaciteten och effektiviteten i de sociala skyddsprogrammen samt stärka koordinationen mellan olika sektioner på nationell och regional nivå. Det föreslagna programmet kommer att utgå från befintliga modeller och fokusera på att koppla kontantöverföringsmottagare till barnskyddstjänster med hjälp av integrerad ärendehantering.
Det kommer att vara en insats med två avtal (ett med WFP och ett med UNICEF). Planen är att bedömningar, revisioner, fältuppdrag och utvärderingar ska utföras gemensamt. Sverige har de senaste tre åren arbetat med att stödja sociala skyddssystem i Kenya tillsammans med WFP samt under de 14 senaste åren tillsammans med UNICEF arbetat med socialt skydd, barnskydd och utveckling och genomförande av olika sorters sociala skyddsmekanismer.
Det nuvarande förslaget är 78 MSEK under tre år, fördelade enligt följande – UNICEF 66 MSEK och WFP 34 MSEK. Eftersom det inte bildats någon ny regering i Sverige efter valet och biståndsbudgeten för 2019 ännu inte är beslutad kommer ambassaden att teckna ettåriga avtal på totalt 40 MSEK med UNICEF (30 MSEK) och WFP (10 MSEK) för 2018. Om den nya regeringen anslår mer medel kan Sverige besluta att avsätta mer medel och förlänga aktivitetsperioden.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Support to UNICEF/WFP Social Protection in Kenya
UN WFP and UNICEF have submitted a joint programme proposal to Sweden for support to the Government of Kenya to provide assistance towards equitable access to social and child protection for a total of 78 MSEK.
The long-term vision for change is an integrated, child-sensitive and shock-responsive social protection system that links beneficiaries to basic social services, so as to benefit an increased number of men, women, boys and girls; from the poorest and most vulnerable households.
The proposal aims at i) Support Technical Assistance to review, develop and implement legislation, processes and strategies on Social Protection(SP) and Child Protection (CP), systems strengthening, ii) Enhanced capacity and increased efficiencies in the delivery of social protection programmes and to iii) strengthen intersectoral coordination linkages at the national and county level.
The proposed programme will use already existing models and focus on linking cash transfers beneficiaries to child protection services through integrated case management.
There will be one contribution with two agreements (one with WFP and another with UNICEF). It is expected that the appraisal, reviews, field missions and evaluations will be conducted jointly. SE in Kenya has worked previously with support to social protection via both WFP over the last 3 years and UNICEF to both social and child protection over the last 14 years in the development and implementation of different aspects of social protection.
The current assessment is for 78MSEK for 3 years distributed as follows - UNICEF 66MSEK and WFP 34MSEK. However, due to the fact that currently there is no government formed in Sweden and the aid budget for 2019 is not yet decided, the Embassy will sign with both UNICEF and WFP a one year agreement in 2018 for a total of 40 MSEK - 30MSEK for UNICEF and 10MSEK for WFP. However, should funds be available after the government appropriation, Sweden can then take a decision to avail more funds and prolong the activity period.

The proposed programme has an overall goal to ensure that people in Kenya, especially the most vulnerable groups, live in dignity, are free from poverty, hunger, violence, abuse and exploitation, to be able to exploit their full human capabilities and contribute to the national development. The original assessment of the objectives and contribution's theory of change still stands save for the current Covid-19 pandemic which has brought in positive aspects of testing the shock-responsiveness of the Social Protection system in Kenya and how to enhance the system to address varying types of shocks which will affect Kenya in future.

description.narrative: Social Protection Government of Kenya (GoK) is gradually shifting towards universal approaches in social protection and UNICEF and WFP are strongly supporting this agenda with technical, financial, and advocacy support. The introduction of a Universal Child Benefit (UCB) in Kenya is a key goal, stated in both the revised policy and the investment plan, and will be a breakthrough for the sector and for the wellbeing of children in Kenya. UNICEF and WFP provided technical and financial support to Ministry of Labour and Social Protection (MLSP) to develop three key strategic documents for the social protection sector. These are an overarching Social Protection Policy, a 10-year Investment Plan and a 5-year Social Protection Strategy. These documents are expected to work synergistically and provide a blueprint to expand and strengthen the sector in the next years The Government of Kenya has developed regulations for the establishment of a Social Assistance Fund within the Public Finance Management Act (2012), with financial and technical support from WFP and UNICEF. Regulations were drafted in August 2019 by a taskforce led by the National Treasury and then tabled before Parliament for a first reading of the Social Assistance Bill 2020. The establishment of a Social Assistance Fund will be a major milestone for the social protection sector in Kenya in terms of enabling enhanced coverage and provision of timely, predictable and adequate benefits to beneficiaries, as well as clear grievances and case management mechanisms The Baseline Survey Report of Kenya’s Inua Jamii 70 Years and Above Cash Transfer Programme was developed by the Government of Kenya with technical and financial support of ILO, UNICEF and WFP, and officially launched on 1st October 2020 on the International Day of Older Persons. This baseline report provides a vital reference point for future impact evaluations of universal pensions and their subsequent effects on human well-being, including poverty alleviation, food and nutrition security Under the overall leadership of WFP, the two partners supported the continued development and enhancement of existing Management Information Systems (MISs), e.g. to accommodate cash plus and shock-responsive models within the framework of the National Safety Net Programme. At the same time, UNICEF and WFP continued to support the strengthening and expansion of the Single Registry, making sure all existing Social Protection MISs are linked to the registry, including linkages to complementary social protection programmes through data-sharing mechanisms. This allows county governments, non-governmental organizations, UN agencies, and other partners who provide complementary services to existing Inua Jamii beneficiaries and other social protection interventions to share data and information for enhanced coordination and integration. UNICEF continued to support the development of an evaluation plan and a set of tailored monitoring tools for monthly, quarterly and annual reporting on the Social Protection sector. The Kenya Social Protection M&E Framework 2018-2022 was initially developed in 2018 based on the 2011 Policy, and it has been updated to align it with the policy as revised in 2019 WFP and UNICEF supported the MLSP to develop, institutionalize and roll out a Learning and Development Curriculum for Social Protection. The curriculum was based on the most critical capacity development needs of the national and county governments as identified by MLSP. In the area of disability-inclusive Social Protection, UNICEF supported three Government Officers to participate in a short-course of University Bonn as part of the UNPRPD-ILO-UNICEF Inclusive Social Protection Initiative, which was conducted from June to November 2020. During the reporting period, WFP and UNICEF initiated a partnership with the National Hospital Insurance Fund (NHIF) to coordinate and support activities linking health and social protection and ultimately aim at mainstreaming NHIF membership into the National Safety Net Programme Child Protection UNICEF continued to work with National Council on Administration of Justice (NCAJ)- Special Taskforce on Children Matters and the National Council for Children Services to advocate for the Children Bill to advance through the various stages of the legislative process to ensure its speedy enactment by parliament. The Bill is currently with the Cabinet. In 2020, UNICEF supported the government to complete three important studies that will inform the policy and programme decisions for strengthening child protection systems and services. The 2018 Census on Street Families and the 2019 Survey on Violence against children were completed and launched by Cabinet Secretary of the Ministry of Labour and Social Protection. The Survey was launched together with the National Prevention and Response Plan to address Violence against Children (VaC). On birth registration, UNICEF supported the Civil Registration Services (CRS) to establish a multi-sectoral technical working group which includes all UN agencies supporting with birth registration and also to facilitate with access to virtual platform (zoom-link) to conduct regular meetings On improved access to justice for children, UNICEF planned to support some of the ‘Big 7’ recommendations highlighted in the Status Report on Children in the Justice System (2019) which UNICEF had provided financial support for its preparation by national Council on Administration of Justice (NCAJ)-Special Taskforce on Children Matters. This was however was not possible with the onset of COVID-19. However, towards the end of 2020, when the situation normalized, UNICEF supported the NCAJ by seconding a child protection officer (National UN Volunteer) to support in the implementation of the Big 7 recommendations. UNICEF is supporting cash plus approaches in three key areas: maternal, newborn and child health (MCNH), nutrition, and energy. Moreover, an additional cash plus pilot currently under design in Mombasa includes a strong focus on disability-inclusive education, alongside a MNCH component. As part of the Covid-19 response, UNICEF Child and Social Protection sections initiated a joint, integrated activity to support children released from residential institutions (both statutory and charitable institution) after their partial closure due to Covid-19 At the same time, the first pilot phase of the Cash Plus Energy programme Mwangaza Mashinani in Garissa and Kilifi counties was successfully concluded, with the last payments going out in July 2020, despite the challenges posed by Covid-19. UNICEF and WFP supported GoK to establish a Technical Working Group (TWG) and a National Steering Committee at national level that include all relevant social protection stakeholders. Moreover, in June 2020, UNICEF and WFP founded the Sectoral Group for Social Protection (SGSP) to gather development partners working in the sector in Kenya. The Sectoral Group aims to ensure that development partners in the social protection sector provide support to the government in a predictable and coordinated manner that aligns with the latter’s strategic development priorities. UNICEF and WFP supported GoK in establishing a Community of Practice (CoP) for Social Protection. Led by the Directorate for Social Protection, the CoP was launched in October 2020 with a high-level event (held virtually, with few government representatives participating in person) and has hosted two webinars so far (Social Protection Adaptations to COVID-19; Launch of the Kenya Social Protection M&E Framework), with a third one being planned at the moment. Social Protection and Child Protection Response to Covid-19 Activities during the reporting period were deeply affected by the Covid-19 outbreak and the resulting movement restrictions. USD 733,293 of UNICEF’s funds from this grant were reprogrammed towards the Covid-19 response and are being used to support the upcoming UCB pilot. Similarly, WFP launched an emergency cash assistance programme for urban vulnerable groups in Mombasa and Nairobi where each targeted household received KES. 4000 per month for a period of three and four months respectively (the cash transfer funds were from USAID and Finland but with the use the system supported by Sida funds). To improve on the national system within the context of a complex emergency, USD 53,000 of this grant was set aside to facilitate an assessment that seeks to explore the social and economic impacts of COVID and how the existing social protection system has enhanced resilience at household level. The findings of this study will be disseminated in high level advocacy events with policy makers. Overall, to support effective coordination and appropriate response to the affected communities, WFP developed an Application Programming Interface (API) for the Enhanced Single Registry (ESR). This system provides an interface that allows a program to communicate with other programs, running in the same environment. Accordingly, different agencies and institutions with long-term and emergency specific social assistance interventions are able to link and use the ESR which in turn enhances greater collaboration among partners, effective use of available resources, increases transparency while supporting appropriate decision making based on available data. title.narrative: Kenya Social Protection Support - UNICEF & WFP
Kenya Social Protection Support - UNICEF & WFP

description.narrative:
FN:s WFP och UNICEF har lämnat ett gemensamt programförslag till Sverige gällande ett stöd på totalt 78 MSEK till den kenyanska staten. Syftet är att bygga upp ett system som ger rättvis tillgång till sociala skyddssystem och barnskyddssystem.
Den långsiktiga visionen är ett socialt skyddssystem som är integrerat, tar hänsyn till barn och fungerar i nödsituationer, som ger förmånstagarna tillgång till ett grundläggande socialt skydd samt att ett ökat antal män, kvinnor, pojkar och flickor från de fattigaste och mest sårbara hushållen får tillgång till detta.
Förslaget går ut på att ge teknisk assistans vid revidering, utveckling och införande av lagar, rutiner och strategier gällande socialt skydd och barnskydd, att förstärka system, öka kapaciteten och effektiviteten i de sociala skyddsprogrammen samt stärka koordinationen mellan olika sektioner på nationell och regional nivå. Det föreslagna programmet kommer att utgå från befintliga modeller och fokusera på att koppla kontantöverföringsmottagare till barnskyddstjänster med hjälp av integrerad ärendehantering.
Det kommer att vara en insats med två avtal (ett med WFP och ett med UNICEF). Planen är att bedömningar, revisioner, fältuppdrag och utvärderingar ska utföras gemensamt. Sverige har de senaste tre åren arbetat med att stödja sociala skyddssystem i Kenya tillsammans med WFP samt under de 14 senaste åren tillsammans med UNICEF arbetat med socialt skydd, barnskydd och utveckling och genomförande av olika sorters sociala skyddsmekanismer.
Det nuvarande förslaget är 78 MSEK under tre år, fördelade enligt följande – UNICEF 66 MSEK och WFP 34 MSEK. Eftersom det inte bildats någon ny regering i Sverige efter valet och biståndsbudgeten för 2019 ännu inte är beslutad kommer ambassaden att teckna ettåriga avtal på totalt 40 MSEK med UNICEF (30 MSEK) och WFP (10 MSEK) för 2018. Om den nya regeringen anslår mer medel kan Sverige besluta att avsätta mer medel och förlänga aktivitetsperioden.

Support to UNICEF/WFP Social Protection in Kenya
UN WFP and UNICEF have submitted a joint programme proposal to Sweden for support to the Government of Kenya to provide assistance towards equitable access to social and child protection for a total of 78 MSEK.
The long-term vision for change is an integrated, child-sensitive and shock-responsive social protection system that links beneficiaries to basic social services, so as to benefit an increased number of men, women, boys and girls; from the poorest and most vulnerable households.
The proposal aims at i) Support Technical Assistance to review, develop and implement legislation, processes and strategies on Social Protection(SP) and Child Protection (CP), systems strengthening, ii) Enhanced capacity and increased efficiencies in the delivery of social protection programmes and to iii) strengthen intersectoral coordination linkages at the national and county level.
The proposed programme will use already existing models and focus on linking cash transfers beneficiaries to child protection services through integrated case management.
There will be one contribution with two agreements (one with WFP and another with UNICEF). It is expected that the appraisal, reviews, field missions and evaluations will be conducted jointly. SE in Kenya has worked previously with support to social protection via both WFP over the last 3 years and UNICEF to both social and child protection over the last 14 years in the development and implementation of different aspects of social protection.
The current assessment is for 78MSEK for 3 years distributed as follows - UNICEF 66MSEK and WFP 34MSEK. However, due to the fact that currently there is no government formed in Sweden and the aid budget for 2019 is not yet decided, the Embassy will sign with both UNICEF and WFP a one year agreement in 2018 for a total of 40 MSEK - 30MSEK for UNICEF and 10MSEK for WFP. However, should funds be available after the government appropriation, Sweden can then take a decision to avail more funds and prolong the activity period.

The proposed programme has an overall goal to ensure that people in Kenya, especially the most vulnerable groups, live in dignity, are free from poverty, hunger, violence, abuse and exploitation, to be able to exploit their full human capabilities and contribute to the national development. The original assessment of the objectives and contribution's theory of change still stands save for the current Covid-19 pandemic which has brought in positive aspects of testing the shock-responsiveness of the Social Protection system in Kenya and how to enhance the system to address varying types of shocks which will affect Kenya in future.

description.narrative: Social Protection Government of Kenya (GoK) is gradually shifting towards universal approaches in social protection and UNICEF and WFP are strongly supporting this agenda with technical, financial, and advocacy support. The introduction of a Universal Child Benefit (UCB) in Kenya is a key goal, stated in both the revised policy and the investment plan, and will be a breakthrough for the sector and for the wellbeing of children in Kenya. UNICEF and WFP provided technical and financial support to Ministry of Labour and Social Protection (MLSP) to develop three key strategic documents for the social protection sector. These are an overarching Social Protection Policy, a 10-year Investment Plan and a 5-year Social Protection Strategy. These documents are expected to work synergistically and provide a blueprint to expand and strengthen the sector in the next years The Government of Kenya has developed regulations for the establishment of a Social Assistance Fund within the Public Finance Management Act (2012), with financial and technical support from WFP and UNICEF. Regulations were drafted in August 2019 by a taskforce led by the National Treasury and then tabled before Parliament for a first reading of the Social Assistance Bill 2020. The establishment of a Social Assistance Fund will be a major milestone for the social protection sector in Kenya in terms of enabling enhanced coverage and provision of timely, predictable and adequate benefits to beneficiaries, as well as clear grievances and case management mechanisms The Baseline Survey Report of Kenya’s Inua Jamii 70 Years and Above Cash Transfer Programme was developed by the Government of Kenya with technical and financial support of ILO, UNICEF and WFP, and officially launched on 1st October 2020 on the International Day of Older Persons. This baseline report provides a vital reference point for future impact evaluations of universal pensions and their subsequent effects on human well-being, including poverty alleviation, food and nutrition security Under the overall leadership of WFP, the two partners supported the continued development and enhancement of existing Management Information Systems (MISs), e.g. to accommodate cash plus and shock-responsive models within the framework of the National Safety Net Programme. At the same time, UNICEF and WFP continued to support the strengthening and expansion of the Single Registry, making sure all existing Social Protection MISs are linked to the registry, including linkages to complementary social protection programmes through data-sharing mechanisms. This allows county governments, non-governmental organizations, UN agencies, and other partners who provide complementary services to existing Inua Jamii beneficiaries and other social protection interventions to share data and information for enhanced coordination and integration. UNICEF continued to support the development of an evaluation plan and a set of tailored monitoring tools for monthly, quarterly and annual reporting on the Social Protection sector. The Kenya Social Protection M&E Framework 2018-2022 was initially developed in 2018 based on the 2011 Policy, and it has been updated to align it with the policy as revised in 2019 WFP and UNICEF supported the MLSP to develop, institutionalize and roll out a Learning and Development Curriculum for Social Protection. The curriculum was based on the most critical capacity development needs of the national and county governments as identified by MLSP. In the area of disability-inclusive Social Protection, UNICEF supported three Government Officers to participate in a short-course of University Bonn as part of the UNPRPD-ILO-UNICEF Inclusive Social Protection Initiative, which was conducted from June to November 2020. During the reporting period, WFP and UNICEF initiated a partnership with the National Hospital Insurance Fund (NHIF) to coordinate and support activities linking health and social protection and ultimately aim at mainstreaming NHIF membership into the National Safety Net Programme Child Protection UNICEF continued to work with National Council on Administration of Justice (NCAJ)- Special Taskforce on Children Matters and the National Council for Children Services to advocate for the Children Bill to advance through the various stages of the legislative process to ensure its speedy enactment by parliament. The Bill is currently with the Cabinet. In 2020, UNICEF supported the government to complete three important studies that will inform the policy and programme decisions for strengthening child protection systems and services. The 2018 Census on Street Families and the 2019 Survey on Violence against children were completed and launched by Cabinet Secretary of the Ministry of Labour and Social Protection. The Survey was launched together with the National Prevention and Response Plan to address Violence against Children (VaC). On birth registration, UNICEF supported the Civil Registration Services (CRS) to establish a multi-sectoral technical working group which includes all UN agencies supporting with birth registration and also to facilitate with access to virtual platform (zoom-link) to conduct regular meetings On improved access to justice for children, UNICEF planned to support some of the ‘Big 7’ recommendations highlighted in the Status Report on Children in the Justice System (2019) which UNICEF had provided financial support for its preparation by national Council on Administration of Justice (NCAJ)-Special Taskforce on Children Matters. This was however was not possible with the onset of COVID-19. However, towards the end of 2020, when the situation normalized, UNICEF supported the NCAJ by seconding a child protection officer (National UN Volunteer) to support in the implementation of the Big 7 recommendations. UNICEF is supporting cash plus approaches in three key areas: maternal, newborn and child health (MCNH), nutrition, and energy. Moreover, an additional cash plus pilot currently under design in Mombasa includes a strong focus on disability-inclusive education, alongside a MNCH component. As part of the Covid-19 response, UNICEF Child and Social Protection sections initiated a joint, integrated activity to support children released from residential institutions (both statutory and charitable institution) after their partial closure due to Covid-19 At the same time, the first pilot phase of the Cash Plus Energy programme Mwangaza Mashinani in Garissa and Kilifi counties was successfully concluded, with the last payments going out in July 2020, despite the challenges posed by Covid-19. UNICEF and WFP supported GoK to establish a Technical Working Group (TWG) and a National Steering Committee at national level that include all relevant social protection stakeholders. Moreover, in June 2020, UNICEF and WFP founded the Sectoral Group for Social Protection (SGSP) to gather development partners working in the sector in Kenya. The Sectoral Group aims to ensure that development partners in the social protection sector provide support to the government in a predictable and coordinated manner that aligns with the latter’s strategic development priorities. UNICEF and WFP supported GoK in establishing a Community of Practice (CoP) for Social Protection.
